LA SRA. GRACIELA ES MUY TRABAJADORA Y CON EL DINERO DEL CREDITO COMPRARA MERCADERIA PARA SATISFACER A SUS CLIENTES LLEVANDO VARIEDAD DE ROPA, YA QUE EN ESTA EPOCA EMPIEZAN LAS CLASES ESCOLARES Y LE REALIZARON MUCHOS PEDIDOS.

LA SRA. GRACIELA ESTA AGRADECIDA CON EMPRENDER Y KIVA POR LA CONFIANZA BRINDADA EN LA OTORGACION DEL CREDITO.
texts.en:
Graciela sells seasonal clothing and she also has a vegetable stand in one of La Paz's busiest streets. She sells her clothes, according to orders placed with her, in Camiri (Santa Cruz province). Graciela has six children, three of whom study higher education and three are still minors attending school. She takes care of supporting her minor children as well as the older ones. She enters Kiva's program via the selection process for this line of work and because of her need. Graciela is very hard-working and she will use the funds to buy merchandise to meet the needs of ther customers with regard to variety of clothing because this is the back-to-school season and she has many orders to fill. Graciela is grateful to Emprender and Kiva for the trust placed in her by granting the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothing.

loans.name: Jackson

texts.en:
Jackson Ibrahim O. is a 63 year old married man. He has seven (7) children. He lives in Igara, in a Busia District where he does dairy farming as his business which he started in 2009 as a source of income. 
He sells milk everyday, but it doesn’t end there, Jackson is looking at a brighter future ahead which will see his business expanding. But to achieve this, financial assistance will be needed. It is for this reason he would like to get a loan worth KSH .20000. These funds would be used to buy enough feed for the cattle and pesticides for vaccination.

loans.use: To purchase feed and vaccines for the cattle.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Ndèye Samb

texts.fr: Ndèye Samb S. est une femme de 46 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 5 enfants. Elle est membre de Banc villageois depuis 2 ans et fait du petit commerce de tissus et de chaussures. Son objectif est de prendre en charge sa famille et d'augmenter son niveau d'épargne.
texts.en:
Ndèye Samb S. is a woman of 46 years. She is married and the mother of 5 children. She has been a member of the Village Bank for 2 years and has a business selling fabrics and shoes. Her objective is to take care of her family and to increase her savings level.

Translated from French by Barbara (B) Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To grow her business selling fabric and shoes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy fish wholesale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy electrical items for resale

loans.name: Anne

texts.en:
Anne Nabwile M. lives in Bukirimo, in the Busia district. She is 30 years old, married, and a mother of five (5) children.
Anne sells fish at Miyanga market, which she ventured into in 2005 due to demand created by customers within that area. Before, she used to do subsistence farming which was not giving her any reasonable income to be able to support her family. With her fish vending business, her life and that of her entire family has been changing and it is for this reason she would like to get a loan worth KSH 25000. This will enable her to add more stock, to expand her business and to be economically stable.
Her future dream is to see all her children get a better education that will guarantee them a better future.

loans.use: increase her stock to expand her business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Ysmael

texts.es:
Ysmael tiene 50 años, es conviviente, tiene cuatro hijos, pertenece al banco comunal “Yanapakuy” de la Asociación Arariwa y tiene un pequeño taller  mecánico. Ya son varios años que se dedica al negocio y le va  bien gracias al empeño que pone su trabajo. Ysmael requiere el préstamo de los 300 dólares, que invertirá en comprar materiales como  pintura, gasolina y tiner.
   
El socio se encuentra agradecido por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma. 

(Yanapakuy es una palabra del idioma quechua que traducido al castellano significa “ayudemos”)
texts.en:
Ysmael is 50 years old, married with four children, and he belongs to the “Yanapakuy de la Asociación Arariwa” communal bank. He has a small auto repair shop and has been in this business for several years. Thanks to his persistence, he is doing well. Ysmael needs a $300 loan, which he will invest in supplies, such as paint, gasoline and thinner. He is grateful for the opportunity offered through this medium and he promises to pay according to the repayment schedule. (The word “Yanapakuy” is a Quechua word, which translates to mean “We will help.”)

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Supplies such as paint, gasoline and thinner

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en:
Hellen W. is a 35 year old married mother of eight children who lives in Bukirimo, Busia District.

After getting married Anne started subsistence farming but in 2005, as the family got larger and with her husband’s income being not enough to sustain their family, she decided to venture into a business selling cereals as an income-generating activity.

Her future dream is to see all of her children getting a better education that will guarantee them a better future, something that will be able to happen only when her business generates a bigger income. It is for this reason Ann is requesting a loan of KES 10,000 to expand her business.

loans.use: To increase her stock and expand her business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying cloth

loans.name: Las Palomas Group

texts.es:
Este grupo se llama: Las Palomas porque el punto de reunión es donde abundan palomas, el grupo lo integran 12 personas Marcelina G. V. y Macedonia H. venden antojitos, Gudelia G. O., Evelia Enedina M. G. y Efigenia P. V. venden dulces y frituras, Emperatriz López S., Luciana Teresa López M. Susana López M. y Maria Eugenia López H. venden productos de belleza por catalogos como son perfumes cremas etc., Antonia M. S. se dedica a bordar huipiles (ropa tipica), Erica Nora R. M. vende calzado por catalogo y Lucia Matilde O. N. tiene un establecimiento fijo donde vende articulos para regalos.
Gudelia es la representante del grupo es casada tiene tres hijos y ella decidio vender dulces ya  desde que inicio con esta actividad hace ya tres años ha obtenido utilidades muy satisfactorias de las que ha podido apoyar a sus hijos junto con su esposo en el sustento apoyarlo para que acudan a la escuela y logren tener su profesión,tambien va a iniciar a vender alimentos a estudiantes y al publico en general ya que pretende obtener mas ingresos.
Con el credito que obtenga de Fundación Realidad va a surtir su negocio en mayor volumen y tambien comprará ingredientes para preparar alimentos comos son: verduras, carnes, mariscos, refrescos, cafe, azucar, huevos, tortillas, aceite, y gas.
Doña Gude como mejor la conocen se siente agradecida por el apoyo que le ha brindado la Fundación y las personas que intervienen en el financiamiento como son los prestatarios de KIVA ya que ella sueña con tener un lugar fijo para vender mas cosas como ella comenta ella recomienda a su gente ya que dice son gente responsables y pagadoras.
texts.en:
This group is called "Las Palomas" ("The Pigeons"), because pigeons are abundant near the place where they hold their meetings. The group includes 12 people: Marcelina G. V. and Macedonia H. sell snacks; Gudelia G. O., Evelia Enedina M. G. and Efigenia P. V. sell sweets and fried foods; Emperatriz López S., Luciana Teresa López M., Susana López M. and Maria Eugenia López H. sell beauty products such as perfumes, creams, etc. from catalogs; Antonia M. S. weaves huipiles (a traditional article of clothing); Erica Nora R. M. sells shoes from a catalog; and Lucia Matilde O. N. has a permanent store where she sells gift items. Gudelia is the group's representative. She is married and has three children. Three years ago, she started a business selling sweets, and since then it has provided her with very satisfactory profits. This income has allowed her to support her children in conjunction with her husband, so that they can go to school and learn a profession. Gudelia also plans to start selling food to students and to the public in general, in hope of further increasing her income. With the loan provided by the Realidad Foundation, she will stock her business with a greater volume of goods, and she will also purchase ingredients to prepare food to sell, such as vegetables, meat, seafood, soft drinks, coffee, sugar, eggs, tortillas, cooking oil and gas for cooking. Doña Gude, as she is called by those who know her well, is grateful for the support provided to her by the Foundation and by the other people involved in the financing, such as KIVA lenders. Her dream is to have a permanent shop where she can sell more products. She reports that she recommends her people, because she says they are responsible and dependable with their payments.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing products to sell and ingredients for prepared food

loans.name: Festus

texts.en:
Festus Irario Etiang’ is a 45-year-old married man and the father of three children. The family lives in Kwirare, Busia District.

Festus used to be a farmer but, with the low income associated with it, he decided to start a retail business in 2004 in which he sells bicycle spares, buying his stock on a weekly basis.

After being taught by KMET ways to generate and save money for economic development, he saw the need to expand his business and, to achieve that, some financial assistance would be needed. He wishes to obtain a loan of KES 20,000 which will be used to increase his stock and, most probably, prepare some land for farming that will ensure his economic stability.

Festus is a man of big dreams.

loans.use: To increase his stock and prepare land for farming

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Rina

texts.es:
Rina, vive en la ciudad del Cusco, tiene 65 años y tiene dos hijas (Edith y Mery). Rina alterna sus actividades del hogar con su trabajo de profesora del colegio “Inca Gracilazo de la Vega” de la ciudad del Cusco. La socia nos cuenta que la situación económica de su familia esta baja entonces decidió dedicarse a otra actividad pues vio la posibilidad de confeccionar chompas de lana. Ya son 26 años que se dedica a la enseñan y le va muy bien gracias al empeño que pone su trabajo. Rina forma parte del banco Comunal “Yanapakuy” de la Asociación Arariwa, ella requiere el préstamo de los 100 dólares, que invertirá en comprar lana y hacer un curso de actualización de confección de chompas de lana. Rina se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
 
(Yanapakuy es una palabra del idioma quechua que traducido al castellano significa “ayudemos”).
texts.en:
Rina is 65 years old and lives in the city of Cusco. She has two daughters (Edith and Mery). Rina alternates between her household duties and her work as a teacher in the “Inca Gracilazo de la Vega” school in Cusco. She tells us that her family’s economic situation is not very good, so she decided to pursue another activity. She saw the possibility of making and selling wool sweaters. She has been teaching for 26 years and, thanks to her dedication, she is doing well. Rina is a member of the “Yanapakuy” de la Asociación Arariwa” comunal bank. She needs a $100 loan which she will use to buy yarn and take a sweater-making class. Rina appreciates this opportunity and promises to repay the loan according to the repayment schedule. (The word “Yanapakuy” is a Quechua word, which translates to mean “We will help.”)

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest in yarn and a sweater making class

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying grocery items

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy ingredients in bulk.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase food ingredients in bulk

loans.name: Daniel

texts.es:
A la vivienda del señor Daniel Velásquez le está haciendo falta los acabados del interior del baño, pero en este momento no cuenta con el dinero necesario para poder llevar acabo la mejora. 
Es por eso que está solicitando un crédito, para comprar el material y pagarle ha la persona que realizara la mejora. 
Planea pagar el crédito con su ingreso que obtiene de su empleo una agencia de paquetería en el departamento de descargas.
texts.en:
Daniel’s home bathroom is missing the finishing touches and he doesn’t have the money to make improvements. He is requesting a loan to be able to buy the fixtures and pay someone to make the improvements. He plans to use his income from his job in the packaging section within his company’s shipping department to repay the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Finishing touches in his bathroom

loans.name: One Way Group

texts.en:
Here are members of the One Way group. They are small scale entrepreneurs in the northern city of Makeni. They are seeking a loan of SLL 1,200,000 per member to enable them to add more goods to their businesses. In this way, they will be able to make more sales and earn more profit. Consequently, they can better support their children in terms of feeding, clothing and schooling. 

Fatmata S. is the leader of this group. She is 40 years of age, born in Makeni City. Fatmata is married and has 3 children. Her husband is an architect and her children attend primary and secondary school. Fatmata sells vegetables, palm oil (the most popular cooking oil) and vegetable oil. She has been in this business for 20 years. With her share of the loan, she will buy vegetables wholesale and gallons of palm and vegetable oils to expand her business.

loans.use: Buy vegetables wholesale and gallons of palm and vegetable oils to expand her business

loans.name: Reunion Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the Reunion group. They are small scale entrepreneurs in the northern city of Makeni. They are seeking a loan of SLL 1,200,000 per member to enable them to add more goods to their businesses. In this way, they will be able to make more sales and earn more profit. Consequently, they can better support their children in terms of feeding, clothing and schooling.

Hassanatu J., 46, is the leader of this group. She was born in Magburaka, in northern Sierra Leone. She currently resides in Makeni, together with her husband and 6 children. 

Hassanatu sells rice and palm oil. She has been a businesswoman for 10 years. With her share of the loan, she will buy more bags of rice and gallons of palm oil for her business.

loans.use: Buy more bags of rice and gallons of palm oil for her business

loans.name: Two Friends Group

texts.en:
These ladies give their group its inspiring name – Two Friends.  They are small scale businesswomen in the city of Makeni who want a loan of SLL 800,000 each to enable them to expand their businesses. This will be their very first loan from SMT/Kiva. With this loan, they will be able to add more goods to their businesses so that they can attract more customers, make better sales, earn more profit and improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Janet S. T.. She was born in Mayamba, in southern Sierra Leone. The 42-year-old is married to a professional worker and they have 4 children. Three of her children are in secondary school and one is in primary school.  For many years now, Janet has been selling rice, oil, sugar and other foodstuffs. With her share of the loan, she will expand her business by buying the above-mentioned items wholesale to add to her current stock.

loans.use: Buy rice, oil, sugar, etc. to add to her current stock

loans.name: Able Group

texts.en:
Pictured above are members of the Able group from the city of Makeni in northern Sierra Leone. They have come to SMT/Kiva Lenders to apply for a loan of SLL 500,000 per member to expand their businesses. With the help of this loan, they can add more goods to their businesses, make more sales, earn more profit and consequently improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Mariatu K.. Mariatu was born in the small town of Yoni, in northern Sierra Leone. The 40-year-old is married to a professional worker and they have 4 children. Two of her children are in secondary school and two are in primary school. For many years now, Mariatu has been selling food at the market: fish, margi (used to give sauce a sweet taste), salt and palm oil (the most popular cooking oil). With this loan, she will buy these foods wholesale for her business.

loans.use: Buy fish, margi, salt, and palm oil wholesale for her business

loans.name: Aracely Margarita

texts.es:
Aracely Cedeño de 35 años, vive en una zona periurbana en Paraíso de Guayaquil, su casa es de cemento y cuenta con todos los servicios básicos, su esposo trabaja en una camioneta haciendo fletes, con el tiene 2 hijos de 18 y 16 años.

Aracely empezó alquilando la lavadora de su casa, después de algún tiempo pudo comprar otra lavadora y comenzó el negocio de alquiler de lavadora.

Ahora ella trabaja alquilando lavadoras todos los días, ella y su esposo transportan las lavadoras a la casa de los clientes, una de las complicaciones que tiene es la transportación de las lavadoras.    

Con el préstamo quiere comprar una lavadora y secadora para su negocio de alquiler de lavadoras, en el futuro quiere ya tener establecido un lugar donde la gente valla a lavar ropa.
texts.en:
Aracely is 35 years old and lives in the suburbs of Paraíso de Guayaquil. She has a cement home with all the basic services. Her husband drives a truck and delivers freight. They have two children, ages 16 and 18. Aracely began renting out her own washing machine and eventually she was able to buy a second machine and started the business of renting out washing machines. Now she rents the machines out daily. She and her husband deliver the machines to her customers’ homes. Transportation is one of their challenges. She will use this loan to buy another washer and dryer to rent to her customers. In the future she would like to start a Laundromat.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Washer and Dryer

loans.name: Active Group

texts.en:
Pictured above are members of the Active group. They are small scale businesswomen in the city of Makeni in northern Sierra Leone. They want a loan of SLL 800,000 each to add more goods to their businesses so that sales and profits will increase. In this way, they can better look after their children in terms of feeding, clothing and schooling.

The leader of this group is Kadiatu S.. Kadiatu, 35, was born in Makeni. She is married and has 5 children. Two of her children are in primary school and three are in secondary school. Kadiatu has been a businesswoman for many years. She sells rice, palm oil, firewood, honey, bulgur wheat and much more.  She will use this loan to buy bags of rice and bulgur wheat to add to her current stock.

loans.use: Buy bags of rice and bulgur wheat to add to her current stock

loans.name: Jesus Obrero Group

texts.es:
ALCANCIA COMUNAL JESUS OBRERO

Lorenza es secretaria D. la Alcancía Comunal JESUS OBRERO, ella es madre soltera D. tres hijos, D. los cuales la mayor ya es una joven independiente, trata D. sacar adelante a sus menores hijos en base a su esfuerzo y dedicación.

Lorenza es una mujer trabajadora y optimista, desD. muy joven trabajó como empleada D. un hogar, pero con la llegada D. su menor hijo se vio obligada a renunciar, porque ya no tenia el tiempo suficiente para criar bien a sus hijos, entonces gracias a la idea y ayuda D. su hermana, empezó su negocio D. vender caldo, trabajo con el que ya tiene 2 años y le da ganancias.

Los planes D. Lorenza son D. alquilar un local más granD. para su negocio, pero su más granD. sueño es comprar un local y ser una gran empresaria en lo que se dedica.
texts.en:
JESUS OBRERO COMMUNAL ALLIANCE Lorenza is the secretary of the Jesus Obrero Communal Alliance. She is the single mother of three children. Her oldest daughter is a young woman who lives on her own. She tries to help her young children get ahead in life through her strength and dedication. Lorenza is a hard working, optimistic woman. As a young woman she worked as a maid, but she had to resign when her first child was born, because she did not have enough time to raise her children well. Thanks to her sister’s idea and help, she started her own business selling soup. She has been doing this for two years and has been making good money. She plans to rent a larger location for her business, but her big dream is to someday buy her own location and become a great entrepreneur.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Rent a larger workspace

loans.name: Julia

texts.es:
Julia, vive en la ciudad del Cusco, tiene 58 años y tiene cinco hijos de las cuales tres son independiente y dos depende de ella todavía (Karina 25 años y Alberto de 23 años). Julia alterna sus actividades del hogar con su trabajo de profesora del colegio “Sagrado Corazón de Jesús” de la ciudad del Cusco. Ya son 28 años que se dedica a la enseñanza pero también la socia tiene un pequeño negocio de venta de pollos, ella nos cuenta que compra pollos pequeños y los hace crecer y engordar y después envía los pollos a su hija a la ciudad de Pilcopata donde los vende. Julia forma parte del banco Comunal “Yanapakuy” de la Asociación Arariwa, ella requiere el préstamo de los 700 dólares, que invertirá en comprar comida para los pollos como harina de pescado, soya, maíz y vitaminas. Julia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
 
(Yanapakuy es una palabra del idioma quechua que traducido al castellano significa “ayudemos”).
texts.en:
Julia lives in the city of Cusco. She is 58 years old and has five children, of whom three are independent and two are still dependents (Karina, age 25, and Alberto, age 23). Julia divides her time between her household activities and her job as a teacher at the Sacred Heart of Jesus High School in city of Cusco. She has 28 years of teaching experience, but she also runs a small business selling chickens.

Julia says she raises and fattens chicks. Afterwards, she sends the grown chickens to her daughter in the city of Pilcopata to sell. Julia is a member of the “Yanapakuy” Communal Bank, which is part of Asociación Arariwa. She is requesting a loan of 700 USD to invest in feed for her chickens such as fish meal, soybeans, corn, and vitamins. Julia is grateful for this opportunity and promises to complete her payments on time.

(“Yanapakuy” is a Quecha word that means “we help”.)

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase chicken feed

loans.name: Francisco

texts.es:
El señor Francisco C. está muy agradecido por su cooperación en el anterior crédito el cual se pudo colocar la losa de concreto en toda la casa.
Nuevamente está solicitando un préstamo para poder terminar los acabados y poder habitar la vivienda, ya que esta pagando renta, desea que su familia ya esté en su propia casa. 
Planea pagar el crédito con el ingreso que obtiene de su trabajo como administrador de un hotel. 
Espero contar nuevamente con su cooperación para este préstamo y así terminar su casa.
texts.en:
Sr. Francisco C. is grateful for the assistance provided from his previous loan, which he used to install a concrete slab in his house. Francisco is now requesting a new loan in order to complete the finishing touches on his home and also install the posts that hold the power lines, which he currently rents. He desires these jobs to be completed for his family so that they can have their own home. He plans to repay this loan from his salary as a hotel manager. He looks forward to receiving your assistance again with this loan so that he can finish his house.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Finish the interior/exterior of his house & install electrical posts

loans.name: Jhon

texts.es:
Jhon, de 26 años, es un joven que desde muy pequeño luchó por brindarle lo mejor a su familia. Vive en la casa que le heredaron sus padres, junto a su hermana Alva de 20, Carlos de 18, Yonatan de 15 y Paola de 13 años, y está dispuesto a trabajar muy duro con tal de cumplir con su deber como hermano mayor.

A la edad de 16 años tuvo que afrontar solo el abandono de sus padres. Al ser el hermano mayor se vio obligado a dejar sus estudios secundarios y empezó a trabajar como “triciclero” (transporte de personas en triciclo), ya que era la única forma que tenía de llevarles un alimento a sus hermanos. 
Con el paso del tiempo logró juntar el dinero necesario para comprarse un motocarro, con el cual ha logrado sacar adelante a sus familia, pues con los ingresos que le genera esta actividad le puede pagar los estudios universitarios y secundarios a sus hermanos, quienes ven en él a un padre, motivo por el cual le tiene mucho cariño y respeto.
Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es la libertad que le brinda en sus horarios, ya que tiene que estar al tanto de que sus hermanos tengan todo lo que necesitan, lleva 8 años realizando esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es tener que permanecer hasta altas horas de la noche trabajando, ya que tiene que llevar la mayor cantidad de dinero a su casa. 
Con el tiempo, espera tener un negocio más estable, tal vez un bodega, pero todavía no se decide, ya que sabe que más adelante sus gastos serán más fuertes.

Este es el segundo préstamo de Jhon con MFP, sabe que tiene que pagar todas sus cuotas a tiempo y está dispuesto a hacerlo. En su banco comunal es muy responsable, ya que no quiere quedar mal ante el resto de sus compañeros. Con los setecientos nuevos soles solicitados hará arreglar las llantas de su motocarro, ya que con el paso del tiempo se han ido desgastando.
texts.en:
Jhon is 26 years old. From an early age, this young man has fought to provide the best for his family. He lives in the house he inherited from his parents with his siblings: Alba (age 20), Carlos (age 18), Yonatan (age 15), and Paola (age 13). He is willing to work very hard in order to fulfill his duties as the oldest brother.

At the age of 16, Jhon had to confront by himself the abandonment by his parents. Being the oldest brother, he was forced to leave high school and begin working as a tricycle driver. This was the only way he knew to be able to feed his siblings.

Over time, he managed to put together enough money to buy a motorcycle taxi, which enabled his family to get ahead. With the income he generated from this business activity, Jhon was able to pay for the college and high school expenses of his siblings. He looks after them like a father, which is why he gains much admiration and respect.

What he enjoys most about his job is the freedom his schedule provides since he has to be aware that his siblings have everything they need. Jhon has been in business for eight years and believes the hardest part of his job is having to work late at night. During that time, he usually has a large amount of money that he has to take home. With time he hopes to open a more stable business, such as a grocery store. He is still undecided, knowing that later there will be larger expenses.

This is Jhon’s second loan with MFP. He knows that he must make his payments on time and is willing to do so. He is very responsible in his Communal Bank and does not want to lose face with the other members. With his loan of 700 soles, he will purchase tires for his motorcycle taxi because they wear out over time.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Puchase tires for his motorcycle taxi

loans.name: Lorenza

texts.es:
Lorenza, D. 60 años, es una madre D. familia muy alegre y trabajadora, vive en su casa propia junto a su esposo Paulino, D. 64 años, y con su hijo Heiler D. 12 años, quienes son el motivo D. todos sus esfuerzos.

El negocio al que se dedica es la venta D. repuestos D. segunda mano D. automóviles, aunque sabe que es un negocio donD. predominan los varones, se siente muy segura en poder competir  sin prejuicios, es por eso que decidió trabajar muy duro y siente que poco a poco sus esfuerzos van dando los frutos esperados, con los cuales pueda ayudar en su hogar. 
Lo que más le gusta D. su trabajo es vender sus repuestos, tiene 30 años D. experiencia y considera que lo más difícil D. su trabajo es conseguir lo repuestos, ya que tiene que recorrer las calles D. la ciudad D. Juliaca en busca D. ellos.
Con el tiempo, espera que su negocio crezca y le pueda brindar lo ingresos necesarios para que su hijo pueda culminar sus estudios.

Este es el segundo préstamo D. Lorenza con MFP, por lo cual se siente en la responsabilidad D. pagarlo a tiempo, ya que quiere acceder a muchos más; en su banco comunal le tienen mucho cariño. Los dos mil nuevos soles solicitados los invertirá en mejorar su negocio y comprar más repuestos para autos y así satisfacer a la gran cantidad D. clientes que tiene.
texts.en:
Lorenza, 60 years old, is the very happy and hard-working mother of a family. She lives in her own house with her husband Paulino, who is 64, and her son Heiler, who is 12. They are the motive for all her efforts. The business to which she is dedicated sells parts for second-hand automobiles. Though she is aware that it is a business in which men predominate, she feels very confident in being able to compete without prejudice. It is for that reason that she decided to work very hard, and feels that little by little, her efforts are providing the fruit that she hoped for, enabling her to help in her home. What she likes most about the work is selling parts. She has 30 years experience and considers the most difficult part to be obtaining the parts, since she has to trek through the streets of the city of Juliaca in search of them. Over time, she hope that her business will grow and offer the necessary income for her son to complete his studies. This is Lorenza's second loan through MFP, and she feels the responsibility to pay on time, since she wants to gain access to many more. The members of her communal bank feel much affection for her. The 2,000 New Sols she solicits will be invested in improving her business and to buy more auto parts, thus satisfying the large quantity of customers she has.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: INCREASING HER STOCK OF PARTS FOR USED CARS

loans.name: Rosa

texts.es:
Rosa, vive en la ciudad del Cusco, tiene 40 años y tiene cuatro hijos de las cuales uno es independiente (Jorge de 22 años) y tres depende de ella todavía (Benito de 25 años, Mari Luz de 12 años y Catherine de 06 años). Rosa alterna sus actividades del hogar con la administración de su pequeño taller de carpintería. La socia nos cuenta que actualmente tiene tres empleados quienes fabrican los muebles. Rosa es madre y padre para sus hijos, ella forma parte del banco Comunal “Yanapakuy” de la Asociación Arariwa, ella requiere el préstamo de los 600 dólares, que invertirá en comprar materiales como madera, tiner y laca. Rosa se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
 
(Yanapakuy es una palabra del idioma quechua que traducido al castellano significa “ayudemos”).
texts.en:
Rosa lives in the city of Cusco, Peru. She is 40 and has four children, one of whom is living independently (Jorge, who is 22). The other three (Benito, 25; Mari Luz, 12; and Catherine, 6) still depend on their mother financially. Rosa balances her work at home with the operation of her small furniture-making workshop. Rosa tells us that she currently employs three people building furniture. She is both mother and father to her children, and is a member of the “Yanapakuy” Communal Bank, part of Asociación Arariwa. The word "yanapakuy" comes from the Quechua language and means "Let's help". She needs a loan of 600 dollars to invest in materials such as wood, paint thinner, and lacquer. Rosa is thankful for the opportunity offered by the lending process and promises to follow the repayment schedule.

Translated from Spanish by Catherine Fountain, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of materials such as wood, paint thinner, and lacquer.

loans.name: Mariela

texts.es:
Mariela, de 24 años, es una joven muy alegre y sencilla, vive en la casa de sus familiares y lo que más desea es sobresalir en la vida.

En la comodidad de su hogar, donde implementó su pequeño taller textil, elabora las gorras más coloridas y llamativas del mercado San José (mercado importante de la ciudad de Juliaca).
Todas las mañanas inicia su actividad diaria y con mucho arte le da forma a los distintos materiales que usa, para convertirlos en las gorras que confecciona. Los fines de semana se da tiempo para distribuir sus gorras entre las vendedoras del mercado, donde ella también tiene su puesto y aprovecha para vender.
Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es tejer y lo hace con mucha habilidad, lleva 4 años realizando esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es tener que realizar los acabados a sus gorras, ya que es muy detallista. 
Para más adelante, espera tener una tienda muy grande, donde pueda vender sus gorras con más tranquilidad.

Este es el segundo préstamo de Mariela con MFP y tiene pensado acceder a otros más, por lo cual quiere pagar puntualmente todas sus cuotas y no traerle problemas a su banco comunal donde es muy querida, ya que es muy responsable. Con los dos mil nuevos soles solicitados comprará más materiales para elaborar nuevas gorras.
texts.en:
Mariela, 24, is a cheerful and unassuming young woman; she lives with her family and her greatest desire is to succeed in life. She set up a small, textile workshop in the comfort of her home. She manufactures the most colorful and eye-catching caps in the San José market (an important market in the city of Juliaca). She starts her work day very early in the morning and she infuses her items with much art and imagination in the use of the various materials in order to convert them into the caps she makes. On weekends, she takes time to distribute her caps among the sellers in the market, where she also has her own sales stall. What she likes most about her work is weaving, something she does quite ably. She has been in this line of work for 4 years and considers the most difficult part of her job having to create the finishings for her caps because she is very detail oriented. For later on, she would like to have a larger store where she can sell her caps more comfortably. This is Mariela's second loan with MFP and she plans to apply for others. For this reason, she wants to repay in a timely fashion and not create problems for her communal bank, where she is a well-liked member, because she is very responsible. She will use the requested 2000 new soles to buy supplies to make new caps.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy textiles.

loans.name: María Micaela

texts.es:
La señora María Micaela P. es una dama muy sonriente que se dedica a la actividad de pulpería teniendo el negocio en el municipio de Cinco Pinos donde a diario desde muy tempranas horas de la mañana vende sus productos tales como comestibles y productos personales.
Ella está solicitando el crédito para la compra de dichos productos para la pulpería entre los que se encuentran comestibles y productos del hogar y así suplir sus estantes y lograr la satisfacción de sus clientes que a diario le visitan en la pulpería que ella tiene en buen dirigir.
texts.en:
Mrs. María Micaela P. is a very smiley lady who works in her grocery store in the town of Cinco Pinos. She begins work very early each day and sells groceries and personal products. She is asking for the loan to buy products for her store, such as groceries and housewares to be able to stock her shelves and improve customer satisfaction for the regular customers who visit her well-managed store.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Meinecke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy products for her store

loans.name: Ana Isaura

texts.es:
En el municipio de Chichigalpa, la señora Ana Isaura M. se dedica a atender su propia pulpería que posee siendo ésta la que le permite obtener los ingresos para el desarrollo y bienestar de su familia. Ella es una dama muy trabajadora que comienza a laborar desde muy tempranas horas de la mañana hasta el anochecer atendiendo a sus clientes que le visitan para la compra de los productos de pulpería.
Está solicitando un crédito para la compra de granos básicos como arroz, frijoles, azúcar, lacteos, entre otros. Espera que su crédito le sea otorgado satisfactoriamente y así continuar en su actividad.
texts.en:
Ana Isaura M. has a small grocery store in Chichigalpa, which is her only source of income and provides for the development and well-being of her family. She is a very hard-working woman, who starts her workday very early in the morning and continues until nighfall tending to her customers, who visit her to buy items from her store. She is requesting funding to buy basic stock items like: rice, beans, sugar, dairy products, among others. She hopes that the loan will be approved so that she can continue working.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy stock items for her store.

loans.name: Aurelia Bibiana

texts.es:
Aurelia, vive en la ciudad del Cusco, tiene 49 años, es madre soltera y tiene cuatro hijos de las cuales todos dependen de ella (Sandra de 20 años, Milagros de 14 años, Elizabeth de 12 años y Juan Carlos de 08 años). Aurelia alterna sus actividades del hogar con la atención de su tienda de abarrotes, ella nos cuenta que acomodo una habitación de su domicilio para expender sus productos. Ya son 5 años que se dedica al negocio y le ha ido muy bien gracias al empeño que pone en su trabajo. Aurelia forma parte del banco Comunal “Yanapakuy” de la Asociación Arariwa, ella requiere el préstamo de los 700 dólares, que invertirá en comprar comestibles como arroz, azúcar, fideos, gaseosas y leche. Aurelia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
 
(Yanapakuy es una palabra del idioma quechua que traducido al castellano significa “ayudemos”).
texts.en:
Aurelia, 49, lives in Cusco. She is a single mother of 4 childlren, all of whom are dependent on her. (Sandra, 20, Milagros, 14, Elizabeth, 12, and Juan Carlos, 8). Aurelia is a housewife but also tends to her grocery store. She tells us that she conditioned a room in her home to sell her products. She has been in this line of work for 5 years now and she has done well, thanks to the effort she puts into her work. Aurelia is a member of Asociación Arariwa's "Yanapakuy" communal bank. She is requesting 700 dolars to buy stock items like: sugar, rice, pasta, soft-drinks and milk. Aurelia is grateful for the opportunity offered by this means and pledges to repay in a timely fashion. (Yanapakuy is a quechua word that means "Let's help")

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy food items like: rice, sugar, pasta, soft-drinks, milk.

loans.name: Los Geranios 1 & 2 Group

texts.en:
Maria is the coordinator of her group, Los Geranios (The Geraniums), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in Los Alcarrizos, a dusty, industrial town where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her long-term partner and their two children.

Maria is excited to be taking her second loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business selling used clothing, which she buys in bulk packages that arrive from places like the Salvation Army. She will use the profits to invest in her children's future as well as improving her home. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: Clothing to sell

loans.name: Natalia De Fátima

texts.es: La señora Natalia E. es propietaria de su propio negocio de venta de gas butano el que es ofrecido en tanques y varias personas le compran el gas para cocinar. Ella siempre busca la manera de cómo satisfacer las necesidades de sus clientes y suplirlas. Es por este motivo que está solicitando un crédito para la compra de los tanques de gas para comercializarlos y de esta manera continuar generando los ingresos para su desarrollo en el municipio de Chichigalpa en Chinandega.
texts.en:
Natalia E. owns her own business in the town of Chinandega, which consists of the sale of butane gas tanks. Several people buy the gas from her to cook with. She always seeks ways to meet her customers' needs and to have supplies on hand. This is why she is asking for funding in order to buy gas tanks to sell so that she can continue to earn income for her development.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cooking gas tanks.

loans.name: Úrsula

texts.es:
La señora Ursula M. se dedica a la venta de verduras en el municipio de Chichigalpa donde ofrece diferentes tipos de verduras tales como papa, cebollas, yuca, entre otros.
La razón por la que ella está solicitando el crédito es para invertirlo en la compra de las verduras tales como la papa, cebollas, yuca, tomate y chiltomas con el propósito de venderlas y de esta manera generar sus ingresos para su desarrollo y el de su familia.
texts.en:
Ursula M. sells vegetables in Chichigalpa. She stocks several kinds of vegetables like: potatoes, onions, yucca, among others. The reason behind her loan request is to buy more vegetables like: onions, yucca, tomatoes and peppers to sell so that she can continue to earn income for her own and her family's development.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy vegetables.

loans.name: Francisco Javier

texts.es:
A la vivienda del señor Francisco Javier B. le esta haciendo falta las bardas alrededor de la casa y las protecciones en las puertas y ventanas. 
Esta solicitando un crédito para poder realizar la mejora lo más pronto posible ya que le han estado robando. 
Desea la seguridad de su familia para poder habitar la vivienda, ya que tiene dos hijos pequeños de edad y quiere lo mejor para ellos. 
Planea pagar el crédito con su ingreso que obtiene de su trabajo en una compañía de paquetería en el departamento de repartidos en la ciudad de Nuevo Laredo.
texts.en:
Francisco Javier B.'s home still needs walls around the property as well as protection on windows and doors. He is requesting funding in order to make the above-mentioned improvements as soon as possible because he has already been robbed. He hopes to provide his family with security so that they can live in their home because he has two, young children and he wants the best for them. He plans to repay his loan using part of his salary as a delivery person employed by a local, Nuevo Laredo, package delivery company.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To build walls and add protection to windows and doors.

loans.name: Ngaya

texts.fr: Ngaya S. est une femme de 48 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 5 enfants. Elle est membre de Banc Villageois depuis 2 ans et a eu 4 bonnes expériences avec le crédit. Elle voudrait acheter une paire de bœufs pour faire de la production laitière afin de générer des profits qui lui permettrons de prendre sa famille en charge et d'augmenter son épargne.
texts.en:
Ngaya S. is a 48-year-old married woman who is the mother of five children. She has been a member of Banc Villageois for two years and has had four loan experiences. She would like to buy a pair of cattle for milk production in order to generate profits that will enable her to support her family and to increase her savings.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing her capital investment

loans.name: Ndèye

texts.fr: Ndèye N. est une femme de 54 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 5 enfants. Elle est membre de Banc Villageois depuis 2 ans et a eu 4 expériences avec le crédit. Elle est éleveuse de moutons et de poulets de chaire. Avec les bénéfices qu'elle réalise elle prend en charge sa famille et augmente son niveau d'épargne.
texts.en:
Ndèye N. is a 54-year-old woman, married and mother of five children. She has been a member of the local “Banc Villageois” loan group for two years and had four prior experiences with credit loans. She raises sheep and chickens. Her earnings enable her to take charge of her family and increase her savings level.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase her working capital

loans.name: Codou

texts.fr: Codou N. est mariée, elle est âgée de 53 ans et mère de 5 enfants. Elle est depuis 2 ans membre du Banc Villageois de A.NDIABOT et y a bénéficié de 4 prêts qu'elle a régulièrement remboursés. Elle fait du commerce de poissons frais. Avec ses bénéfices elle parvient à assurer la dépense quotidienne de sa famille.
texts.en:
Codou N. is married, 53-years-old and the mother of five children. For the past two years she has been a member of the “Banc Villageois” loan group of A. NDIABOT where she was granted four loans, all repaid on time. She sells fresh fish, and with her earnings is able to manage family daily expenses.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase her working capital

loans.name: Ignacia

texts.es:
La señora Ignacia P. ya ha tenido dos créditos con FVP los cuales a pagado puntualmente y le han ayudado a mejorar su vivienda.
Solo le esta haciendo falta los acabados del interior, es por eso que está solicitando un préstamo para poder tener su casa terminada. 
Planea pagar el crédito con el ingreso que obtiene de su trabajo en una fábrica en el departamento de elaboración.
Ya que es soltera y la única persona que depende económicamente de ella es su mama que es una persona mayor de edad. 
La persona que aparece en la foto es la mama de la señora Ignacia P. ya que ella se  encontraba en su trabajo el día de la visita.
texts.en:
Ignacia P. has had two previous loans with FVP which she has repaid on time. They were used for home improvements. All she needs still is to finish the interior. She is asking for funding in order to finish her house. She plans to repay the loan with part of her salary working in the assembly area of a factory. She is single and the only person who depends upon her economically is her elderly mother. The person in the photo is Ignacia P.'s mother because Iganacia was at work when the home visit was made.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For interior finishing touches.

loans.name: Khoudia

texts.fr: Khoudia N. est mariée et mère de 3 enfants. Elle est âgée de 55 ans et membre de Banc Villageois depuis 2 ans. Elle fait de l'élevage de poulets et développe en même temps un petit commerce de chaussures et d'écharpes. Elle vise à améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Khoudia N. is married and mother of three childrenn. She is 55 years old and has been a member of the local « Banc Villageois » loan group for two years. She raises chickens and is also starting a small shop where she sells shoes and scarves. Her aim is to improve her family’s living conditions.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase her working capital

loans.name: Luciano

texts.es: Don Luciano es casado, habita en la Cmca. Polvasan de la Libertad junto a su familia,  tiene 4 hijos, 2 mayores de edad de su primer matrimonio, y 2 con doña Joselina de 19 y 16 años respectivamente,  los cuales le apoyan con el trabajo de la finca.  Su actividad principal es la comercializacion de leche, pero ademas se dedica a engordar y desarrollar terneros y los vende cuando pasan de 300 kg.  Esta solicitando su 8vo credtio para comprar 6 terneros para engordarlos, desarrollarlos y venderlos cuando tengan buen peso, y obtener mejores ganancias que le permitan el sosten familiar, su finca cuenta con las condiciones necesarias para realizar esta actividad, la cual realiza desde hace varios años.  Su mayor deseo es poder realizar sus negocios como los tiene previstos y mejorar su finca ya que es el patrimonio de su familia.
texts.en:
Luciano is married and lives in Polvasan de la Libertad with his family. He has 4 children, 2 from his first marriage, who are adults, and two with Josefina, who are 19 and 16 years old respectively and who help out with the farm chores. His main commercial activity is dairy farming but he also raises cattle which he sells when they reach a weight of 300kg. He is asking for his 8th loan in order to buy 6 calves to fatten up, develop, and sell when they reach the required weight, so that he can earn better profits that will allow him to support his family. His farm has the required conditions for this type of activity which he has been undertaking for several years. His greatest wish is to have his businesses as he envisions them and to improve his farm because it is his family's only asset.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy calves.

loans.name: Fatou

texts.fr: Fatou D. est une femme de 27 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 5 enfants. elle est membre de Banc Villageois depuis 2 ans et a bénéficié de 4 près qu'elle a bien gérés et remboursés. Elle développe un petit commerce de tissus, de jus de fruits naturels et de bouillie de mil. son objectif est d'assurer la prise en charge de sa famille et d'augmenter son épargne.
texts.en:
Fatou D. is a 27-year-old woman, married and mother of five children. She has been a member of the local “Banc Villageois” loan group for two years, and was granted four loans, which she managed well and repaid in full. She is starting up a small store dealing in fabrics, natural fruit juices and millet porridge. Her objective is to take care of her family’s needs and to increase her savings.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase her working capital

loans.name: Marvin

texts.es: Marvin M. de 25 años de edad es soltero, trabaja para el MINED desde hace 7 años como  docente de primaria en una comarca llamada Flor Sur del  Municipio de Nueva Guinea, este joven vive con sus ancianos padres ya que todavia no ha formado su propio hogar, con el salario que este profesor gana ayuda a sus padres con los gastos familiares y va mejorando su vivienda, Marvin con este 2do crèdito que solicita pretende construir su propia habitaciòn y asi tener privacidad ya que actualmente comparte la habitaciòn con un hermano, su mayor sueño es seguir estudiando y culminar su carrera de ciencias de la Educaciòn, estabilidad laborar y cumplir con el sueño de tener su propia habitaciòn .
texts.en:
Marvin M., 25, is single and has worked for the Ministry of Education as an elementary school teacher in Flor del Sur, Nueva Guinea, for the last 7 years. This young man lives with his elderly parents since he hasn't yet formed his own family. He uses the salary he earns as a teacher to help his parents meet household expenses and to gradually improve their home. This is Marvin's second loan request and he plans to use the funds to build his own bedroom so that he can have some privacy; he currently shares a bedroom with his brother. His greatest wish is to continue studying and complete his degree in Education, to have employment stability, and to have his dream of having his own bedroom come true.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To build a bedroom.

loans.name: Yamilex Del Socorro

texts.es: Yamilex de 30 años de edad, trabaja como responsable de Recursos Humanos en la Universidad URACCAN de Nueve Guinea, es madre soltera de un niño de 9 añitos de edad estudiando su 4to grado de educaciòn primaria,  tiene 3 años de laborar para la Universidad Uraccan Recinto Nueva Guinea,  actualmente vive con sus ancianos padres a quienes cuida y los ayuda en todo lo que esta a su alcance. Yamilex  esta estudiando una maestrìa en docencia universitaria ya que su mayor sueño es ser una profesional con mucha experiencia, ella se caracteriza por ser trabajadora, responsables de buenas costumbres y bien sociable en el Municipio, esta solicitando su 9no credito el cual lo requiere para hecharle el piso a una habitaciòn y hacerle algunas mejoras que le hace falta para tener mejores condiciones y poco a poco mejorando la infraestructura de la casa para el bienestar de sus padres y de su hijo.
texts.en:
Yamilix, 30, works in the Human Resources department of the Nueva Guinea campus of URACCAN University. She is a single mother of a 9-year-old son, who is in 4th grade. She has worked for the university for 3 years. She currently is living with her elderly parents, whom she cares for and helps out with everything in her ability. Yamilex is studying for her masters degree in university education. Her greatest wish is to be an experienced professional. She is known in her town for being very hard-working, responsible, of good habits, and very sociable. She is asking for her 9th loan, which will be used to pay for the installation of flooring in a room and to make some other improvements that are needed so that it will be in better condition thus gradually improving the home's infrastructure for the benefit of her parents and her son.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To install flooring.

loans.name: Mame Penda

texts.fr: Mame Penda D. est âgée de 55 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 5 enfants. Depuis 2 ans elle est membre de banc villageois. Elle fait de l'import, sa marchandise composée essentiellement de vêtements et d'ustensiles de cuisine est en provenance de Dubaï. Elle cherche à améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille et à assurer la scolarité de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Mame Penda D. is 55-years-old, married and mother of five children. She has been a member of the local « Banc Villageois » loan group for two years. She imports goods from Dubai, mainly clothing and kitchen utensils. She strives to improve her family’s living conditions and provide schooling for her children.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase her investment capacity

loans.name: Maricela

texts.es: Maricela de 30 años de edad es soltera, tiene 6 años de laborar para Universidad URACCAN como responsable del Bienestar Estudiantil, tiene un niño de 6 añitos de edad acaba de culminar su pre escolar, ella vive en casa de sus padres por que se le hace mas facil el cuido del niño, pero posee su casa propia, actualmente esta estudiando un curso de Formacion, Gestiòn y Evaluaciòn de proyecto,  está solicitando su 2do credito con el cual pretende comprar una computadora portatil para asi tener un medio trabajo que le permita desempeñarse mejor en sus estudios y el trabajo, ya que aprovecharia el tiempo por las noches para realizar sus trabajos de la Universidad, su sueño es que su hijo tenga mucha salud, estabilidad laboral y cumplir con sus sueños cada vez que se lo proponga.
texts.en:
Maricela, 30, is single. She has worked for the URRACAN University, in the Student Welfare department, for 6 years. She has a 6-year-old son, who has just completed pre-school. She lives in her parents' house because this facilitates child care, but has her own house. She is currenty taking a course in Project Design, Development and Evaluation. She is requesting her second loan with which she will buy a laptop computer so that she can have a more efficient way of doing her school work and her work since she takes advantage of nighttime hours to do her university work. Her dream is that her son be healthy, to have employment stability and to meet every goal she sets up for herself.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a computer.

loans.name: Maria Del Rosario

texts.es: Doña Marìa del Rosario de 43 años de edad, labora para el ministerio de educaciòn desde hace 22 años como docente, tiene 3 hijos, 2 mayores de edad los cuales ya estan casados y la hija menor de 14 años actualmente estudia en el instuto Rubèn Darìo de Nueva Guinea, su esposo se dedica a trabajar en la finca cerca de la colonia San Juan y le ayuda con los gastos familiares, ellos son una familia bien humilde y bien unida, doña Maria està solictando su 3cer credito con el cual pretende construir un pozo, ya que en la colonia se va bastante el agua y este le vendria a beneficiar ya que no se atrazaria con los quehaceres del hogar en sus horas libres, su mayor sueño es que su familia permanezca bien unida y estabilidad laboral y mejorar las condiciones de vida de su familia siempre que este a su alcance.
texts.en:
Marìa del Rosario, 43, has worked as a teacher for the Ministry of Education for the last 22 years. She has three children, two of whom are married adults. Her youngest daughter, 14, is enrolled in Nueva Guinea's Rubèn Darìo institute. Her husband is a farmworker near San Juan and he helps her with household expenses. They are a close-knit, hard-working family. Maria is asking for her 3rd loan with which she plans to dig a well because water supply in her neighborhood is often interrupted. The well would be of great benefit to her because she wouldn't have to postpone her houshold chores, during her time off from work, while waiting for water service to resume. Her greatest wish is that her family stay together, to have employment stability, and to improve her family's living conditions to the extent that it is in her hands to do so.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To dig a well.

loans.name: Fe Y Amor 4 Group

texts.en:
Carmen, 35, is a borrower who lives in Santiago, Dominican Republic. She is the coordinator for her group, Fe y Amor (Faith and Love), and her story is representative of those in her group and other Dominican and Haitian borrowers at Esperanza International.

Carmen and her husband have two children and live in a simple home in Santiago, the second largest city in the Dominican Republic. Urban areas of the Dominican Republic are highly overcrowded and can be rough, with no potable running water, frequent power outages (if one has power to begin with), and inadequate health care. Despite these difficulties, Carmen runs a successful “salchicha” (hot dog) stand. With this loan, she plans on purchasing more hot dogs, bread for buns, and a new stand to display the hot dogs and other sandwiches.

This is Carmen’s second loan with Esperanza International, and she hopes to continue taking out loans to expand her business and improve home life for her family. With her profits, she hopes to purchase a stove for her home and some shoes and books for her children. Carmen also hopes to add some fun around the house by purchasing a pet for her kids, while also teaching them about responsibility and ownership. Carmen has high hopes for her children, and with profits from her loans, she is confident that they will receive a great education and attain a step up in their lives.

Esperanza International seeks to free children and their families through initiatives that generate income, education and health, restoring self-worth and dignity to those who have lost hope. We have over 8,500 active associates in eleven offices in the Dominican Republic and Haiti. Thank you for lending to Carmen and the Fe y Amor group!

loans.use: Hot dogs, bread, and a new hot dog stand

loans.name: Amistad 6 Group

texts.en:
Noemi is the coordinator of her group Amistad (Friendship), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in the areas surrounding El-Seibo, an agricultural community where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple, rented structure with her husband and their child.

Noemi is excited to be taking her fifth loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loans and expanded her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business, running a beauty salon, by purchasing shampoos, rinses, hair dyes and other hair products. She will use the profits to invest in her current home by refinishing the floors and in her children by purchasing a computer for their education. Her long term goal is to purchase her own home. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: Hair products for her beauty salon

loans.name: Yacine

texts.fr: Yacine C. ets une femme de 47 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 2 enfants. Elle est membre de Banc Villageois depuis 2 ans et a une expérience de 4 prêts qu'elle bien gérés. Elle Fait un petit commerce de parfums, de couscous et d'arachides. Son objectif est de prendre en charge sa famille et d'augmenter son épargne.
texts.en:
Yacine C., 47, is married and the mother of two children. She has been a member of her Village Bank for two years and has gathered experience with the four loans she has received and has managed well. She has a little business selling perfume, couscous, and peanuts. Her goals are to support her family and add to her savings.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: add to her working capital

loans.name: Viviana

texts.es:
Viviana se dedica compra venta de bolsitas de condimentos estos productos los comercializa  en las tiendas y ferias de barrios además trabaja como, lavandera de nylon.

Vive en la  Av. Hawai de la  Zona San Juan Rió Seco.

 Tiene dos hermanastros los cuales quedaron huérfanos y ella se hizo responsable ellos se encuentran en edad escolar.
 
El crédito lo destinara para la  compra de material de construcción para la limpieza de habitación.
 
Es el primer crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada la califica para otorgarle el préstamo
texts.en:
Viviana makes a living by buying and selling condiment pouches. These products are sold to stores and at neighborhood fairs. In addition, she works as a nylon washer. She lives on Hawai Avenue in the District of San Juan Rió Seco. Her two younger brothers are orphans, so she is now responsible for them since they are still of school age.

This loan will be used to purchase construction materials needed to spruce up her house. This is Viviana’s first loan with IMPRO. Her evaluation indicates she is qualified to receive this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase construction materials for her house

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Working capital.

loans.name: Bagna Jessica

texts.es:
Bagna García de 38 años, vive en una zona periurbana en Paraíso de Guayaquil, su casa es de cemento y cuenta con todos los servicios básicos. Su esposo es comerciante con el tiene 2 hijos de 7 y  9 años ellos son estudiantes de escuelas fiscales.

Bagna empezó en la esquina de su casa vendiendo lápices, cuadernos, plumas, poco a poco sus ingresos fueron aumentando y puso un local grande en su casa.

Ahora ella trabaja todos los días desde las 09:00 hasta las 23h00 vendiendo papelería, cuadernos, lápices, marcadores etc. Hasta ahora no se le ha presentado ninguna complicación en el negocio.

Con el préstamo quiere comprar cuadernos, lápices, marcadores para su negocio. En el futuro quiere tener una tienda con víveres bien surtida.
texts.en:
Bagna García is 38 years old and lives in the peri-urban district of Paraíso in Guayaquil. Her house is made of cement and has all the basic services. Her husband works as a merchant and they have two children, ages 9 and 7. Both are students enrolled in public schools.

Bagna began selling pencils, notebooks, and pens on the street corner in front of her house. Over time she was able to increase her earnings and open a large store in her home. She now works every day from 9am to 10pm selling stationery, notebooks, pencils, markers, and other items. Until now, she has not encountered any difficulties with her business.

With this loan, Bagna plans to buy notebooks, pencils, and markers for her business. In the future, she wants to open a well-stocked grocery store.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase notebooks, markers, and pencils

loans.name: Jesus Es Prosperidad 1 & 2 Group

texts.en:
Berenice, 29, is a borrower who lives in Santiago, Dominican Republic. She is the coordinator for her group, Jesus es Prosperidad (Jesus is Prosperity), and her story is representative of those in her group and other Dominican and Haitian borrowers at Esperanza International.

Berenice and her husband have two children and live in a simple home in Santiago, the second largest city in the Dominican Republic. Urban areas of the Dominican Republic are very overcrowded and can be rough, with no potable running water, frequent power outages (if one has power to begin with), and inadequate healthcare. Despite these difficulties, Berenice runs a small blacksmith’s business. With this loan, she plans on purchasing more materials for her business, specifically welding rods and other metalworking supplies.

This is Berenice’s fifth loan from Esperanza International, and she hopes to continue taking out loans to grow her business and improve the home life of her family. With the profits, she hopes to purchase a computer for herself and her children. Computers are one of the best investments for a low-income household, especially the children, as they teach desperately needed technological knowledge.

Berenice hopes that continued business will help her reach her dreams for her business and provide a good education for her children.

Esperanza International seeks to free children and their families through initiatives that generate income, education and health, restoring self-worth and dignity to those who have lost hope. We have over 8,500 active associates in eleven offices in the Dominican Republic and Haiti. Thank you for lending to Berenice and the Jesus es Prosperidad group!

loans.use: To buy welding rods and other materials for metalworking

loans.name: Aminata

texts.fr: Aminata F. est âgée de 56 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 7 enfants. Elle est membre de Banc Villageois depuis 2 ans et a bénéficié de 4 prêts qu'elle a bien gérés et remboursés à temps. Elle fait du petit commerce de pâte d'arachide, de pagne, de bijoux et de parfums. Son objectif est de constituer une forte épargne afin de prétendre à une autonomie financière.
texts.en:
Aminata F., 56, is married and the mother of 7 children. She has been a member of her Village Bank for two years and has received four loans which she used wisely and reimbursed in a timely manner. She sells peanut butter, African print waxcloth, costume jewelry, and perfumes. Her goal is to have sufficient savings so that she can claim to be financially independent.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: bolster her little business

loans.name: La Proyeccion De San Jose Group

texts.es:
MILY, TIENE 23 AÑOS D. EDAD, TIENE DOS PEQUEÑOS HIJOS QUE VIVNE CON ELLA JUNTO CON SU PAREJA. HACE DOS AÑOS INTEGRA EL GRUPO "LA PROYECCIÓN D. SAN JOSÉ", JUNTO CON 10 PERSONAS MAS QUIENES LA ELIGIERON CON LA PRESIDENTA DEL GRUPO, EN RECONOCIMIENTO A SU DEDICACIÓN AL TRABAJO Y RESPONSABILIDAD. ELLOS RESIDEN EN LA ZONA D. SAN JOSÉ EN EL DISTRITO D. CARABAYLLO.
HACE DOS MESES INICIÓ SU NEGOCIO D. VENTA D. SALCHIPAPAS,ELLA SE UBICA CON SU CARRITO SANGUCHERO EN UNA AVENIDA PRINCIPAL, DOND. OFRECE SUS POLLOS BROASTES, HAMBURGUESAS Y SALCHIPAPAS.
CON ÉSTE TRABAJO EN ÉSTE CORTO TIEMPO HA PODIDO COMPRAR ALGUNAS COSAS PARA SU CASA Y AYUDA EN LA ECONOMÍA D. SU HOGAR.
LE GUSTARÍA MAS ADELANTE TENER SU PROPIO RESTAURANTE, EN UNA ZONA CONCURRIDA
EL PRESTAMO SOLICITADO LO DESTINARÁ PARA LA COMPRA D. LOS PRODUCTOS NECESARIOS PARA OFRECER SU COMIDA Y COMPRAR BEBIDAS GASEOSAS.
texts.en:
Mily, 23, has two small children, who live with her and her partner. She has been a member of the "LA PROYECCIÓN D. SAN JOSÉ" communal bank for the last 2 years along with 10 other fellow members, who elected her group president, in recognition of her dedication to work and her responsibility. They all lifve in the San Jose area of Carbayllo district. Two months ago she started to sell salchipapas (fried potatoes with hot dogs). She sets up her cart in one of the main avenues; she sells broasted chickens, hamburgers and salchipapas. This work has allowed her to purchase, in a relatively short period of time, some things for her house and it has contributed to the family's economic stability. She would like to have her own restaurant one day in a busy part of town. The funds requested will be used to buy needed ingredients for her meals and to buy soft-drinks.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy ingredients for her meal preparations and to buy soft-drinks.

loans.name: Mujeres Luchadoras 4 Group

texts.en:
Gabina, 38, is a borrower who lives in Santiago, Dominican Republic. She is the coordinator for her group, Mujeres Luchadoras (Fighting Women), and her story is representative of those in her group and other Dominican and Haitian borrowers at Esperanza International.

Gabina and her husband have three children and live in a simple home in Santiago, the second largest city in the Dominican Republic. Urban areas of the Dominican Republic are very overcrowded and can be rough, with no potable running water, frequent power outages (if one has power to begin with), and inadequate healthcare. Despite these difficulties, Gabina runs a successful “miscellaneous” store, mostly selling clothing. With this loan, Gabina plans to purchase clothing, shoes, and sheet sets to sell for a small profit to her friends and neighbors.
 
This is Gabina’s fourth loan with Esperanza International, and she hopes to continue taking out loans to grow her business and improve the home life of her family. With the profits, she hopes to pay for the construction of new walls in her home. Construction is typically done in stages in the Dominican Republic: as cash becomes available, one builds new parts of the home. The new walls would give her family more privacy and create a more comfortable space in which to live. Gabina will also purchase schoolbooks and shoes for her children.

Gabina hopes to continue her dream as a businesswoman, as well as provide a great education for her children with her business profits.

Esperanza International seeks to free children and their families through initiatives that generate income, education and health, restoring self-worth and dignity to those who have lost hope. We have over 8,500 active associates in eleven offices in the Dominican Republic and Haiti. Thank you for lending to Gabina and the Mujeres Luchadoras group!

loans.use: To purchase clothing, shoes and sheet sets

loans.name: Cristo El Salvador Group

texts.es:
ALCANCIA COMUNAL “CRISTO EL SALVADOR”

La Alcancía Comunal “CRISTO EL SALVADOR” es llamada así porque sus miembros son personas muy católicas y han encontrado un soporte en su religión.
Lucia es una de ellas, ya que tras la pérdida de su esposo quedó viuda a cargo de sus 7 hijos, entonces tuvo que apoyarse en su fe para continuar adelante, y así lo hizo, pudo criar a sus hijos hasta verlos adultos, todo gracias a su trabajo que consistía en lavar ropa y en apoyo que sintió al tener fe en Cristo, pero ahora a sus 65 años Lucia enfrenta otro reto, perdió a 2 de sus hijos dejándola a cargo de sus 3 nietos.
Lucia tenía que trabajar para criar a sus nietos, pero el trabajo de lavar ropa ya no es recomendable para su salud, y entonces gracias a una donación Lucia recibió una carreta ambulante para la venta de dulces, gaseosas, galletas, etc.
Lucia piensa usar el préstamo de EDAPROSPO-PROSPERIDAD, para llenar su carreta ambulante de los productos surtidos que necesita para poder obtener dinero y así cumplir su sueño que es el de poder ver a sus nietos grandes y prósperos.
texts.en:
“CRISTO EL SALVADOR” COMMUNAL BANK Christ the Savior communal bank is so-called because its members are devout Catholics, who have found support in their religion. Lucia is one of them because her husband's death left her a widow with 7 children to support. She had to lean on her faith in order to continue on. She did so and was able to raise her children until they became adults. She did all this taking in laundry and trusting in her faith in Christ. But now, at the age of 65, Lucia faces a new challenge: the deaths of two of her children has left her in charge of three grandchildren. Lucia must work to support her grandchildren but taking in laundry is no longer feasable at her age. Thanks to a donation, Lucia received a pushcart that she can use to peddle sweets, soft-drinks, cookies, etc. Lucia plans to use EDAPROSPO-PROSPERIDAD's loan to stock her pushcart with an assortment of products that she can sell to raise money and see her dream of having her grandchildren grown and properous, come true.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy stock items.

loans.name: Sembrando Esperanza Group

texts.es:
EDWIN,TIENE 23 AÑOS DE EDAD, TIENE UNA HIJA DE POCOS MESES DE NACIDA. ÉL INTEGRA EL GRUPO "SEMBRANDO ESPERANZA" JUNTO CON NUEVE PERSONAS MAS, CARACTERIZADOS POR SER MUY TRABAJADORES. EEDWIN FUÉ ELEGIDO POR SUS COMPAÑEROS COMO SECRETARIO DE LA JUNTA DIRECTIVA DEL GRUPO.
EDWIN TRABAJA HACE OCHO MESES BRINDANDO SERVICIO DE TRANSPORTE A PASAJEROS MEDIANTE UNA MOTO TAXI QUE LE ALQUILA SU SUEGRO, EDWIN RECONOCE QUE ES LA PERSONA QUE MAS APOYO LES HA BRINDADO PARA INICIAR UNA VIDA EN FAMILIA CON SU PAREJA.
CON ÉSTE TRABAJO ÉL PUEDE MANTENER A SU FAMILIA Y PUDO HACERSE CARGO DE LOS GASTOS DEL NACIMIENTO DE SU HIJA, TRABAJA DURO PARTA PODER ADQUIRIR MAS ADELANTE SU PROPIA MOTO.
CON EL PRESTAMO SOLICITADO INVERTIRÁ EN LA COMPRA DE PRODUCTOS DE TRATAMIENTO DE SALUD.
texts.en:
Edwin, 23, has a daughter that's a few months old. He is a member of the "SEMBRANDO ESPERANZA" communal bank along with 9 other members; they are all noted for being hard-working. Edwin was elected group secretary by his fellow members. For the last 8 months, Edwin has worked providing transportation with a mototaxi that he leases from his father-in-law. Edwin recognizes that his father-in-law is the person who has most supported him as he starts out family life with his partner. This work allows him to support his family and he was able to pay for the expenses related to his daughter's birth. He works hard in order to earn enough to buy his own mototaxi some day. He will use the funds to pay for health treatment products.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For health treatment products.

loans.name: La Fe Group

texts.en:
Adriana is the coordinator of her group, La Fe (The Faith), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the Dominican Republic from Haiti) clients generally.

Adriana’s group is located in El-Seybo, an agricultural area where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her longtime partner and their two children.

Adriana is excited to be taking her fourth loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loans and built her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business with a mobile stand that sells the essentials such as chicken, rice, oil and vegetables which she will purchase with this loan.

Adriana will use the profits to invest in her home by refinishing the floor and purchasing food for her family. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To buy chicken, rice, oil and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Marta Edith

texts.en:
Marta Edith V. S. is a 41-year-old mother of two who lives in Golfito de Puntarenas, located in the southern region of Costa Rica, near the Panamanian border. Her highest level of formal education obtained is the completion of 6th grade.

Marta has a business selling pet food and animal feed products named ¨Alimentos Rioclaro¨ which translated as Nutrients of Rioclaro. Marta opened her business five years ago with an initial investment of 700,000 colons. In a successful month, she can expect to earn 24,000,000 colons; in a bad month, only 7,500,000. She uses her earnings to re-invest in her business, to pay debts, to cover personal costs and to finance the schooling of her children.

Marta sells feed that benefits various types of animals including dogs, cats, cows, chickens and pigs among others. Every eight days, she travels to San Vito de Coto Brus in order to purchase supplies from the factory. She purchases large bags of feed weighing 23 or 46 kilograms. By separating it into smaller one kilogram bags, she is able to offer her clients a choice to purchase large or small amounts of feed.

Marta´s store is the only authorized distributor in Golfito for products produced by the supplier in San Vito (a relationship which has been guaranteed not to change).

Marta plans to use this loan to pay off outstanding debts she holds with feed suppliers. She hopes to be able to pay off her loan before the end of the term so as to avoid paying some interest charges.

Marta’s goal is to obtain a higher level of freedom in her business through increased amounts of working capital. She also hopes to earn more income as this will improve her family’s standard of living.

loans.use: To pay off outstanding debts with feed suppliers

loans.name: Almida Del Carmen

texts.es:
Almida E. de 46 años, vive en una zona periurbana en Paraíso de Guayaquil, es madre soltera tiene una hija de 16 años que estudia en un colegio fiscal.

Almida empezó hace 5 años haciendo peluches como distracción, poco a poco comenzó a elaborar muchos peluches y decidió venderlos.

Ahora ella trababa todos los días elaborando peluches, almohadas con su hija, en ocasiones tienen que quedarse hasta la madrugada haciendo los peluches, ella vende los peluches pequeños a $ 6.00 y los grandes a $ 15.00. Una de las complicaciones que tiene es la competencia China que hay en el sector.

Con el préstamo quiere comprar Felpa, accesorios, maquina para coser para su negocio. En el futuro quiere arreglar su casa para poner el local para vender los peluches.
texts.en:
Almida E., 46, lives in a periurban area of Paraíso de Guayaquil. She is a single mother of a 16-year-old daughter, who is in public school. Almida began making plush toys 5 years ago as a hobby. Son enough, however, she was making so many that she decided to sell them. Now, she works daily manufacturing plush toys and pillows with her daughter.
