Occasionally, they have to stay up until dawn making them. She sells the small ones for $6.00 and the large ones for $15.00. One of the obstacles she faces is the competition from Chinese products in the area. She will use the funds to buy felt, accessories and a sewing machine. In the future, she would like to modify her house in order to set up a store to sell her plush toys.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Felt, sewing machine, patterns.

loans.name: Guadalupe

texts.es:
Guadalupe tiene 36 años, vive con su pareja y sus dos hijas; Juana de 11 años y Yasmin de 5 años. Su casa es pequeña y hecha a base de esteras.   
Desde hace muchos años atrás trabaja como ama de llaves, por lo que recibe una remuneración mensual. Paralelamente, por las tardes vende anticuchos (brochetas) en un puesto que acondiciona a 3 cuadras de su casa. A inicios se quedaban con algunos anticuchos, lo cual significaba pérdida para ella, pues no tenía refrigeradora y la carne se malograba.
Pero su perseverancia, la llevó a incrementar sus ventas y estabilizar su negocio, hoy los días de mayor demanda son lo fines de semana, cuando reúne mayor cantidad de dinero.
Ella está muy contenta con lo que hace, por eso todas las noches se esmera en preparar el aderezo de los anticuchos, para que estén sabrosos y no se quede con ninguno.
A Guadalupe no le importa pasar el frío de la noche, solo tiene como meta construir su casa de material noble, para ello sabe que tiene que trabajar arduamente, y asegura que hará realidad sus sueños.

Este es su tercer crédito que tiene con MFP y está comprometida a pagar puntualmente, como en sus anteriores créditos. Asimismo, está conforme con el trabajo de su grupo, puesto que todas son sus vecinas, y son muy responsables. El dinero que ahora solicita lo invertirá en la renovación de su parrilla para poder cocinar más porciones del platillo que vende.
texts.en:
Guadalupe, 36, lives with her partner and their two daughters: Juana, 11 and Yasmin, 5. Their house is small and made of straw matting. For many years now she has worked as a housekeeper, for which she gets a monthly salary. At the same time, though, in the afternoons, she sells anticuchos (various grilled meats on skewers) in a stand that she sets up 3 blocks from home. Sometimes, she had some anticuchos left over, which meant a loss for her, because she did not have a refrigerator and the meat would spoil. However, she persevered, increased her sales and stableized her business. Today, her greatest demand is on weekends and this is when her earnings are highest. She is very happy with her work so she puts her best effort every night into preparing the seasoning for the meat so that it will be delicious and she won't have any left over at the end of the day. Guadalupe isn't affected by the cold of night; her only goal in sight is to build her house with more substantial materials. In order to do so, she knows that she must work very hard and she assures us that she will see her dreams come true. This is her third loan with MFP and she pledges to repay in a timely fashion. Aslo, she is satisfied with the work her group is doing because all the members are her neighbors and all are very responsible. The funds requested will be used to refurbish her grill so that she can cook more of the items she sells.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a grill.

loans.name: Nelida

texts.es:
Nelida es una mujer trabajadora y sobre todo solidaria. Tiene 54 años, vive con su esposo y su hijo Walter de 28 años en su casa propia ubicada al sur de la ciudad de Lima.  

Todas las mañanas y de lunes a viernes es la encargada de cobrar el pasaje y llamar pasajeros para la combi (camioneta) de trasporte público, donde su esposo es el chofer. Se levanta muy temprano, porque a las 5.30 debe estar desayunando, ya que la gente se desplaza con más frecuencia desde las 6.00  a 10.00 de la mañana
A Nelida le gusta realizar está actividad en apoyo a su esposo, porque los otros ayudantes que tenía no le deban todo lo cobrado y otros se fugaron con el dinero. En vista de lo ocurrido, ella se convirtió en su ayudante permanente, esta labor ya la realiza hace 10 años y también lleva la administración de las ganancias de la camioneta.
Ella manifiesta que le gusta lo que hace, aunque tiene problemas en la garganta debido a los gritos que suele hacer para llamar a los pasajeros y marcar las rutas, lo hace con cariño.
Para el futuro se ha proyectado en terminar la construcción de su casa y vivir del alquiler de las habitaciones que planea construir, mientras tanto seguirá trabajando en el transporte para alcanzar sus sueños.

Este es el segundo crédito que tiene con MFP y ratifica su compromiso, como la primera vez de ser responsable con sus pagos. Además tiene mucha gratitud a los integrantes de su grupo, ya que gracias a ellos pudo acceder al préstamo que le permite seguir trabajando hasta el momento. El dinero que ahora solicita lo piensa invertir en la compra de 4 llantas para su camioneta, para dar un mejor servicio a sus pasajeros.
texts.en:
Nelida is a hardworking woman who is responsible above all. She is 54 years old and lives with her husband and her son Walter (age 28) in their own home located south of the city of Lima.

Every morning from Monday through Friday, she is in charge of selling passenger tickets and attracting customers for her public transport minibus, which is driven by her husband. She wakes up very early and has breakfast by 5:30am since people travel more frequently between the hours of 6am to 10am. Nelida enjoys helping her husband in this activity because other assistants they have hired have either undercharged on the travel fare or ran off with all of the money. In light of these occurrences, she decided to become her husband’s permanent assistant. She has worked in this position for ten years and also manages the expenses related to the vehicle. Nelida enjoys what she does, but she has had problems with her voice because of the constant shouting necessary to attract customers and identify travel routes. However, she continues to perform her job with great affection. In the future, she hopes to finish building her house. Her family lives in a rental home while the construction takes place. In the meantime, she continues to work in transportation so that she can achieve her dreams.

This is Nelida’s second loan with MFP. She renews her commitment to be responsible with her payments, just as she did with her first loan. Nelida is also grateful to the members of her group because they helped her with accessing the loan needed for her business to continue. The money she is requesting will be used to purchase four tires for her minibus so that she can provide better service to her passengers.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase tires for her minibus

loans.name: Juana

texts.es:
Juana es casada, tiene 32 años de edad y vive junto a su esposo y sus cinco menores hijos en el caserío San Bernardino, distrito de Túcume, ubicado a 30 minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se dedica a brindar servicio de costura desde hace 15 años. Ella realiza su trabajo en su vivienda, donde tiene instalado un pequeño taller. Allí atiende los pedidos de los clientes que usualmente recurren a su negocio ya que los trabajos que realiza son de muy buena calidad.

Ella nos comenta que este negocio es de mucha ayuda para la economía de su hogar, ya que su esposo trabaja como agricultor y los ingresos que percibe no son suficientes para mantener el hogar. Juana se encuentra solicitando por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1000 nuevos soles que piensa invertir en el mantemiento de su máquina de coser, así como en la compra de material para comenzar a confeccionar prendas de manera independiente.

Juana es una mujer creativa, laboriosa y que gusta mucho de su trabajo. Su mayor anhelo es poder instalar una bodega en su casa con la que pueda seguir apoyando a los suyos.
texts.en:
Juana is 32 and married. She lives with her husband and their five minor children in the San Bernardino neighborhood of the Túcume district. It is located 30 minutes from the city of Chiclayo. She has devoted herself to sewing services since she was 15. She works in her house, where she has a small, well equipped shop. She takes care of her customers’ orders; they usually turn to her because she does very good quality work. She tells us that this business is a big help to their household economy. Her husband works as a farmer, but his income is not enough to support the household. For the first time Juana is asking Edpyme Alternativa for a loan for 1,000 PEN. She plans on using it for maintenance on her sewing machine. She will also buy material to start making clothes independently. Juana is a hard-working and creative woman who really likes her work. Her greatest desire is to be able to set up a convenience store in her house. That way she would be able to continue supporting her loved ones.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Sewing machine maintenance and to buy material

loans.name: Soledad

texts.es:
Soledad tiene 33 años de edad, es madre soltera vive en casa de sus padres los cuales 
le ayudan a cuidar a su menor hija, Ella inicio el negocio de venta de ropa hace 
algunos años, con un pequeño capital producto del trabajo como obrera de planta. Ella 
ya posee una gran cantidad de clientes a los cuales les brinda además de buenos 
precios una buena atención y garantía en la mercadería que les vende, con los 
excedentes obtenidos en esta labor adquirió a crédito una mototaxi la cual le 
genera mayores ingresos. Soledad sueñan con brindarle a su hija y a sus padres una 
condición de vida adecuada, además con tener su casa propia, Soledad destina todos los 
ingresos para la educación de su hija ya que ella esta en edad escolar y la manutención de sus padres.
texts.en:
Soledad, age 33, is a single mother. She lives in her parents’ house, and they help take care of her young daughter. She started her business of selling clothes some years ago. She started with a small amount of capital that she got as a worker in a plant. She already has a large number of customers. Besides offering them good prices and good service, she guarantees the merchandise that she sells. She used the profits from this business to buy a “mototaxi” (three wheeled motorized vehicle) on credit. The mototaxi generates greater income. Soledad dreams of giving her daughter and her parents decent living conditions in addition to having their own house. Soledad puts all of he earnings towards her school-age daughter’s education and towards supporting her parents.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Work capital

loans.name: Jorge Luis

texts.es:
Jorge tiene 25 años, es soltero y vive en casa de sus padres. El se dedica a la venta 
de ropa en forma ambulatoria hace mas de 1 año aproximadamente. Cuenta con ingresos 
adicional por su trabajo como obrero en un fundo agroexportador, es ayudado en el 
negocio por su sobrina cuando esta laborando. La mayor parte de sus ventas son al 
crédito, con lo cual obtiene una mayor rentabilidad, su negocio ha progresado desde 
que se inicio y con el cual ha obtenido un pequeño ahorro para la compra de una 
mototaxi y así tener otro ingreso extra; ya que su sueño es poner una tienda de 
venta de ropa en el centro de la ciudad y para la cual requiere una mayor inversión y 
esta trabajando para que ello sea en un corto plazo. Es una persona responsable y con 
un trato muy cordial por lo que cuenta con regular clientela. Cabe mencionar que el 
crédito que esta solicitando lo requiere para completar el dinero para la compra de su 
mototaxi.
texts.en:
Jorge, age 25, is single and lives in his parents’ house. He has been selling clothes as a traveling salesman for approximately one year. He gets additional income as a workman in the agro-exporting field. His niece helps him in the business when he is working. Most of his sales are on credit, which gives him greater profitability. His business has progressed since he started, and he has some small savings to buy a “mototaxi” (three wheeled motorized vehicle) in order to have extra income. His dream is to set up a clothing store in the center of the city. In order to do so, he needs bigger investment. He is working in order for that to happen soon. He is a responsible person. He treats people very cordially, and that is why he has regular customers. He needs the loan he is requesting to augment the money he has to buy a mototaxi.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Capital de trabajo

loans.name: Sum

texts.en:
Sum Y., age 48, is an internal staff member in the organization, earning a salary of $100 per month. She currently lives with other family members in a wooden house located on a commune in the province of Battambang. She is married with three school-aged kids, who are dependent on their parent’s income. Sum Y.’s husband is the chief provider for the family. He is a professional Khmer lecturer for a local public class. 

Sum Y. and her husband face difficulties travelling to work or anywhere else because they do not have a vehicle. To solve this problem, Sum Y. is applying for a loan to add to her personal money in order to buy a motorcycle.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle

loans.name: Ruon

texts.en: Mrs. Ruon E. is 37 years old and lives in a commune in Battambang province. She leaves home each day to buy vegetables from nearby farmers. She then delivers them by bicycle, door-to-door around her community. She has been engaged in this trade over a year. Ruon E. has a partner in her husband, who is skilled in building wooden houses. The couple work together to feed their three unmarried children. Ruon E. will use her first loan to rebuild part of her old house that needs repair.

loans.use: To rebuild her old house.

loans.name: 02.08.1.8 Nam Ngan Group

texts.en:
Thuy C. T. is a 41-year-old woman living in the town of Thanh hoa. Thuy is the leader of a seven-member group with a loan from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 02.08.1.8 Nam Ngan. 

Thuy is married and has two grown children. She owns and operates a business raising livestock. WhiL. not the only means of generating revenue, raising cattL. for saL. is the main source of income for the business. Thuy has been engaged in this business for over five years and earns approximately 1.200.000 VND a month from these activities.


In 2009, Thuy joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and the ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1.963.500 VND from the Fund. This loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell. She is now requesting a new loan of 6.000.000 VND which will also be used to purchase additional baby livestock. The loan will be the third loan taken out by the borrower from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Thuy plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About the Other Borrowers in the Group:

1.  P. T. Gai is a 55 year-old woman who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business running a food stall.

2.  N. T. Phuong is a 41 year-old woman who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock.

3.  N. T. Thao is a 31 year-old woman who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her fishing business.

4.  D. T. Trinh (43) is a 33 year-old woman who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business running a food stall.

5.  T. T. Bay (44) is a 34 year-old woman who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her general store.

6.  L. T. H. Thanh (45) is a 21 year-old woman who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business running a general store.

About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainabL. financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese whiL. providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell

loans.name: Roeun

texts.en: Mrs. V. is 57 and the mother of one school-aged child and three who are married and live independently. She is a farmer who has been planting a variety of crops for many years. Her husband, a supervisor, helps her run the enterprise. In addition, V. digs a pond behind her house where she raises small fish which she sells when they are mature. Recently, she has needed more money to supply her fish-raising business, so she is requesting a loan of $1100. She proposes to use any remaining money from the loan to buy an old motor to get around.

loans.use: To supply her fish-raising business.

loans.name: Josephine's Group

texts.en: Josephine P.'s main source of income comes from selling personal products such as lotion and underwear in her community. She is 44 years old, married and has five school-aged children. They are from the village of Minallo, Naguilian, Isabela. Josephine has been in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2007, Josephine joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Josephine has successfully repaid a previous loan of 18,000 PHP from ASKI which was used to purchase products to sell. Josephine is requesting a new loan of 22,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her seventh loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business. Josephine is the leader of a 12 member group accessing a loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members, if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is "Josephine P.". About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Lenie's Group

texts.en: Lenie B. owns and operates a general store selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in her community. She is 24 years old, married and has one small child. They are from the village of Dabburab, Cauayan City, Isabela. Lenie has been in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,500 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2009, Lenie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Lenie is requesting a loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase products to sell. This will be her second loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue to supplement her family's income. Lenie is the leader of a 6 member group accessing a loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members, if someone is delinquent or defaults. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Socorro

texts.en:
Socorro M., age 55, is from the town of Alicia, Isabela. She is widowed and has two adult-aged children. To make a living, Socorro works in the services sector. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing manicure and pedicure services to local community members. Socorro has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Socorro joined ASKI to gain access to financial services. Her goal was to help improve her living situation and increase her ability to engage in business activities. Socorro is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide manicure and pedicure services. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Socorro from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide manicure and pedicure services

loans.name: Enhgerel

texts.en:
Enhgerel, age 37, and her husband live with their three children in Umnugobi province. In 1997, Enhgerel decided she wanted to improve the life of her family, so she and a friend went into town and got involved in the clothing business. When she started, she only had 1.5 million Tugrugs. Now the business is worth 5.5 million. Once a month, Enhgerel gets new products from Beijing. Because she only buys high-quality products and receives them from Beijing, the clothes she offers are usually better than those offered by the other sellers.  

Enhgerel needs a loan so she can purchase more apparel from Beijing. Her goal is eventually to have enough money to embark upon her real dream job: opening her very own pastry bakery and shop.  

Her husband, Enhbayar, was crew foreman until an accident at work punctured one of his eardrums and left him partially deaf, a condition that persists even after attempts to have it corrected.  He now works as a delivery man for the vendors in town. 

Enhgerel and Enhbayar live with their children in their own ger (a Mongolian felt tent lived in by nomads). They have twins, Tseveenjav and Tseveensuren, age 16, and a son, Arvinbileg, age 10. They are all happy and healthy. 

Enhgerel is a humble, pleasant person who believes her dreams are just on the horizon.

loans.use: To purchase more apparel for sale

loans.name: Leonida's Group

texts.en:
Leonida B., age 61, is from the village of Manaring. She is married and has children. Leonida is the group leader of a nine-member group loan offered through ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Leonida's name is the official name of this borrowing group.

To make a living, Leonida owns and operates a business venture in the food sector, making and selling breads, cakes, and cookies to members of the local community. Leonida has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Leonida joined ASKI to gain access to financial services. She wanted to help improve her living situation and increase her ability to engage in business activities. Leonida has successfully repaid a previous loan  from ASKI. Leonida is now requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make her baked products for sale. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Leonida from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make baked products for sale

loans.name: Marlyn

texts.en:
Marlyn G., age 21, is from the village of Banquero, Reina Mercedes, Isabela. Marlyn is married and has two small children. To make a living, Marlyn runs a general store where she sells a variety of different products to members of the local community. Marlyn has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Marlyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services. She wished to help improve her living situation and increase her ability to engage in business activities. Marlyn is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Marlyn from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Merlita

texts.en:
Merlita P. is from the village of Centro 2, Mallig, Isabela. She is 48 years old. Merlita is married and has 8 school-aged children. To make a living, Merlita owns & operates a business venture in the services sector managing a tailoring business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing general alteration & tailoring services to local community members. Merlita has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Merlita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Merlita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional fabric & materials. Merlita is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to renovate her tailoring shop. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Merlita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to renovate her tailoring shop

loans.name: Saidahmad

texts.ru: Гоибов Саидахмад проживает в городе Куляб. Возраст, 36 лет. Женат, имеет 7 детей. Жена, домохазяйка. Двое сыновей помогают отцу. Сам Саидахмад более 15 лет занимается торговлей на рынке. Он в основном продает сельскохозяйственые продукты. Кредит берет для увеличения товараоборота.
texts.en:
Saidahmad G. lives in the town of Kulyab. He is 36 years old. He is married and has seven children. His wife is a housewife. His two sons help him. Saidahmad himself has been selling on the market for more than fifteen years. He mainly sells vegetables. He is taking out a loan to increase sales.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase sales and turnover

loans.name: Samwel

texts.en:
Samwel O. is 53 years old. He is married and has six children. His wife is a business woman and they hope to educate their children to university level. 
His business is located at the busy Jubilee market in Kisumu. He sells oranges, mangoes, apples and other fruit to the local people. He has been operating this business for the past ten years. His major challenge is that he sells highly perishable goods which he has to move quickly. There are also many other people running the same kind of business and he, therefore, has only a small number of loyal customers.
He is using his loan to restock his business. In future he wants to have his own orchard. This would allow him to increase his supply of fruit into Kisumu city and also extend his supply into Nairobi city. He also hopes to buy a pick-up truck to transport his fruit. He is very hardworking and patient.

loans.use: to purchase stock

loans.name: Bobojon

texts.ru: Сармисов Бободжон проживает в районе Восе. Возраст, 25 лет. Женат, имеет 2 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Сармисов Бободжон имеет медицинское образование. Он торгует более 6 лет на рынке. Бободжон в основном занимается продажей национального вида продукта "Курут". Кредит берет для увеличения товараоборота.
texts.en:
Bobojon S. lives in the region of Vose. He is 25 years old. He is married, has two children. His wife is a housewife. Bobojon has medical education. He has been selling on the market for more than six years. Bobojon mainly sells traditional Tajik type of product Kurut. He is taking out a loan to increase sales.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase sales

loans.name: Purity

texts.en:
Purity A. A. is 24 years old. She is married and has two children. Her husband is a driver and they hope to send their children to good schools. 
Her business is located at Nyalenda in Kisumu. Kisumu is the lake region in Kenya. Fishing and selling fish are common businesses in the region.  Purity also sells fish to the local people. She has been in this business for the past two years and says her major challenge is that there are so many people in the same type of business. Customers are spoilt for choice and are, therefore, not loyal. She is, however, very determined to grow her business and is using her loan to buy more fish. She sees herself supplying in large quantities to the people of Kisumu.

loans.use: To purchase fish to sell

loans.name: Esther Wanjiru

texts.en:
Esther is a 53 year old widow. She has 5 children: 2 sons and 3 daughters. She lives at Kangemi which is densely populated.

Esther owns many rental houses. She has been in this business for a long time and, through this work, she has been able to provide for herself and her children. She has rental houses in Kangemi near the highway. This is a strategic location as many people prefer living near the highway where there is easy access to roads.

She has been a member of KADET for some time now and this is her fourth loan. She was introduced to KADET by one of the members. She has no previous credit history. The loan she has applied for will be used to connect electricity to her rental houses and to pay school fees for one of her sons.

Esther wants to buy another plot and build more rental houses away from her in-laws who keep harassing her, especially after her husband died.

loans.use: to connect electricity to her rental houses and pay school fees for her son

loans.name: Betty Nyaranga

texts.en:
Betty L. is 33 years old, is married, and has four children who are all in school. Her firstborn son joined high school early this year while her last-born is in kindergarten. 

Betty is looking for a loan through KADET to help her to add more stock to her business. She intends to buy three bales of flour, six kilograms of sugar and some cooking oil.

Betty’s shop is situated in the village away from the town centre and this causes her to get many customers who buy from her instead of traveling miles away to the supermarkets. Her clients consist mainly of local consumers who live in the area.

Betty intends to use the profits to benefit her family in paying school fees for her children and also paying for the family upkeep. Her husband is currently jobless and this makes her work hard to put food on the table.

loans.use: To add more stock to her store

loans.name: Mary Wanjira

texts.en:
Mary is single and 36 years old. She lives in Kirinyaga Road, near Nairobi. 

Mary was introduced to KADET by an existing client. She has never borrowed elsewhere and this is her first loan. Her customers are mainly people within the offices whom she supplies to food. She gets food orders from the offices and occasionally requests to cook for weddings.

Currently Mary works from home and she aspires to open up a food stall from where she can conveniently meet her customers' needs. She has been making food for sale in her house for the last nine years.

The loan Mary has applied for will be used to expand her business and, if possible, to open up a food kiosk or stall. As part of her long term plans, she intends to open a hotel (restaurant) where her customers can locate her.

loans.use: To expand her business and open a food kiosk

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace A. O. is thirty-five years old. She is married to a peasant farmer and they have two children. Her children are still young and she and her husband hope that they will be able to give the children a quality education.

Grace’s business is situated by the roadside at Manyatta Estate in Kisumu. Before opening a stall, she used to hawk her goods (go door-to-door) to the people of Kisumu. She has been doing this business for the last four years and she is very determined to continue growing her business until she opens a boutique.

Grace says that her major challenge is sustaining customers as there are many people doing the same kind of business as hers.

Grace is using her loan to buy more clothes to expand her business. She is a very hardworking and responsible lady.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Lenny Achieng

texts.en:
Lenny O. is a lady from Migori who is married to Samuel O.. They have two children: Monica, who is in primary school, and Millicent, who is in high school.

Lenny is a tailor in Migori town. She has been doing this tailoring business for the last four years and has thus created a big clientele due to the fact that she normally looks out for the latest designs and this makes her beat her competitors.

Lenny is looking for a loan through KADET to enable her buy more sewing machines as well as employ one person to help with the increasing demand for clothes. She took another loan previously and repaid it well, giving her a good credit history.

Lenny intends to use the profits to educate her children to university level and to improve their living standard. Her future plan and hope is to expand her business by opening a tailoring school in her area.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine and add to her stock of fabric

loans.name: Jumabubu's Group

texts.en:
In Kyrgyzstan, not far from its capital, there is a town which is named Kara – Balta. The citizens of this town are hardworking people and most of them have their own livestock and work in the fields. One of these citizens is Jumabubu O. a sixty-one-year-old widow who brought up five children: three of them are daughters and two are sons and now all live separately with their husbands and wives. Jumabubu’s husband was also hardworking and they bought a cow with their savings. Later on they sold it and bought two cows with the proceeds. Unfortunately, as life is an unpredictable thing, her husband died from a heart attack, leaving all his children and the little farm on Jumabubu’s brittle shoulders. Nowadays, Jumabubu is a caring grandmother who has her little farm. She does animal husbandry and sells milk and also rears cattle. She has expanded her livestock and has already married off her children. Now she wants to marry off her grandchildren as well. Thirty years ago, nobody thought that this family, with 15,000 soms ($340) in their pocket, would succeed one day, especially after their grief, but they did. Now her profit is 11,500 soms ($262). Jumabubu wants to obtain a loan to buy ten sheep to raise and sell. Gulnara S. is forty and is married with four children: two sons and two daughters. Her elder children attend the local school and the younger one is a preschooler. She wants to give a high level of education to her children and to buy a big house as well. Her husband transports passengers. Now, Gulnara sells milk and breeds cattle. Everything started with 10,000 soms ($228) which they got from selling their harvest and which they used to buy a cow. Now they already bought a car, a tractor and have increased their head of livestock. With the loan they will buy a heifer to raise. Kuldjamilya K. is a fifty-four-year-old widow who has three daughters and a son. Her elder daughters are married and live separately; her younger daughter works in the shop and her son is busy about the house. Her children already received an education. Kuldjamilya is a seamstress, making national garments. About forty years ago for cost of about 5,000 soms ($114) she and her husband bought a heifer. Now, from selling milk and other items, they earn 2,100 soms ($43) per month. They are planning to increase their head of livestock and to build a barn and a fence. The loan will be used to buy a heifer to raise. Arsygulbek M. is a married man at the age of forty nine. He has five children to whom he wants to give a good education and he also wants to buy a house. Three of his children are sons and two are daughters. His spouse is a housewife. His elder daughter is married, the second one works in the garment factory, his son is busy about the house and the youngest ones go to the local school. Arsygulbek’s wife and son always help and encourage him. They sell milk and look after cattle while he works as a taxi driver. A few years ago they bought a cow for 12,000 ($273) and thus they started their business. Now their profit is 8,400 soms ($190) per month. Arsygulbek wants to obtain a loan to increase the total number of their cattle. ====================================== --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.
Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy ten sheep to raise and sell

loans.name: Sambath

texts.en:
Mrs. Sambath C., 51, and her husband, Mr. Rin Penh, 51, live on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have been married since 1975 and have seven children: two daughter and five sons. Two of the children are married and live outside the family home, two daughters weave silk at home and the others attend school.

Sambath has been a silk-weaver since she was young, a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to a middleman who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. Mr. Rin Penh is a security guard.

Sambath is requesting her first loan of $1,000 to buy a motorcycle for commuting and to purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle for commuting and silk for her weaving

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret A. M. is forty-five years old. She is married and they have four children who are still schooling.

Margaret’s business is located at the busy Kibuye market in Kisumu, Kenya, and it's well known by the name Konyando Traders. She has been selling material, kitenge (African traditional cloth) and school uniforms for the last fifteen years. The majority of her customers are women and parents of school-going children.

Margaret’s major challenges have been lack of enough capital and too many people doing the same business as hers. She also faces harassment from the local government but she is determined to make her business a success.

Margaret is using her loan to buy more material and a sewing machine to grow her business. She hopes to build her own premises in the future and grow her business to become the leading supplier of clothes and material in Kisumu city. She is a very honest, strict and hardworking lady.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine and add to her stock of fabric

loans.name: Corazon

texts.en:
Corazon O. is 59 years old and lives in La Castellana, Negros Occidental. She is a widow and has been caring for her two children since 1985. She makes her living by selling soft drinks and frozen foods in the local markets. She is also a rice retailer - buying and selling sacks of rice. With her food business, she gets contracts from Iloilo in the province of Panay to the north of Negros Occidental.

Before joining Project Dungganon in 2002, Corazon sold products door-to-door, including ready-to-wear (used) clothing and Avon beauty products. With her loan from Project Dungganon, she was able to expand her frozen foods business and eventually move into the rice dealing business. Her current loan of 15,000 pesos will be beneficial in making investments in her business.

Corazon has a son and a daughter who have both graduated from college and are off on their own. She is incredibly proud of their achievements since they both chose to become public servants. Her daughter is a teacher in the national high school and her son is a policeman. Corazon has a 3-month-old grandson with her son.

Eventually, Corazon plans to move out from her present house and settle down in one of the nicer subdivisions. She has already bought a plot of land but cannot afford to build a home yet. She needs Php 100,000 – about $2,500 – to build a house. One day she will get that home while still being a member of Project Dungganon.

Corazon is a member of good standing. She is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.


 About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her rice-selling and food-vending businesses

loans.name: Rosita's Group

texts.en: Rosita A. is from the town of Usol Jones, Isabela. She is 41 years old and is the group leader of a ten-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Rosita A.. Rosita is married and has two school-aged children. She owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month. Rosita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from ASKI. Rosita plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Shadi

texts.en:
"I am taking this loan from FATEN to purchase birds and feed which I sell at my store. I believe that this will improve my financial situation and provide enough money for me to get married," Shadi G. tells us.

Shadi is a 27-year-old single young man from Gaza City, and an employee of the government. He owns a store and is shown in the photo standing in front of his birds. The store is in an excellent location in Gaza's market which is close to the shore.

Shadi is thinking of expanding his business by selling ornamental fish in addition to birds and feeds. He believes that this would be a successful idea as it's the first of its kind in Gaza city.

loans.use: To purchasing more birds and feed

loans.name: Melania

texts.en: Melania L. is a 59-year-old married woman who lives in Barangay Poblacion 1, Sagay City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living operating her general store and restaurant. Melania’s husband, Teotimo, helps his wife in running the business. They have seven children: some adults and some of school age. The children who are currently going to school also help their parents in the business as part of their daily chores. Melania joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2000 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in her general store and restaurant. Now she earns an average monthly income of Php 10,000. Melania is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of Php 10,000 was used to fund operations for her general store, and had a positive impact on both her business and on the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing Php 19,500 for her 13th loan which she intends to use on the general store and restaurant. Melania is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which are to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital for her business

loans.name: Thoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Thoeun C., 42, and her husband, Mr. Lay Sok, 46, (pictured together) have been married since 1993 and have four children: three sons and one daughter. Three of the children attend school and the other one assists her parents in the business. The family is living in a small village off of National Road Number Two, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Thoeun has been growing vegetables and raising pigs for more than fifteen years and her husband assists her in the business. Thoeun hopes to continue expanding her business, so she is asking for a loan of $1,000 to purchase additional piglets and feed for her pigs. She also will use a part of her loan to build a fence around her property.

loans.use: To buy piglets, pig feed and to build a fence

loans.name: Luzviminda

texts.en:
Luzviminda a 45-year old married woman from a barangay (district) called Manghanoy in La Castellana. She is married and has four children between the ages of 6 and 21. She is a very busy woman, acting as an entrepreneur and member of Project Dungganon as well as the treasurer of her barangay.

Luzviminda runs several businesses like a pig-fattening operation and a rice-retailing business. Using her loan from Project Dungganon (NWTF’s micro-finance division), she is going to purchase more rice to resell. She buys approximately twenty-five sacks of rice at a time, at approximately 1,500 pesos per sack. She is able to sell them for 1,700 to the community, for a profit of 5,000 pesos for each set of twenty-five.

One major problem is that sometimes the creditors don’t remember to pay their debts, which means Luzviminda has to wait. More often than not she is paid for her wares, though it can be a struggle. Eventually she would like to own a parcel of land of her own. Manghanoy is a good area for farming, with rich soil.

One of Luzviminda’s children just graduated from college and is looking for a job.  Luzviminda has job working as a treasurer, handling the distribution of the government money for her community. She has to go to the barangay hall every day to work with the barangay officials in handling the finances, keeping records, writing reports, etc. She is compensated at 6,000 pesos per month, and is certainly earning it with all of the work she is putting in. During the day, her husband helps to take care of her piggery.

Luzviminda is a member of good standing. She is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family which are to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.


 About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her rice-retailing business

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en: Mary Ann J. is from the village of Centro 1. She is 44 years old, is married, and has six school-aged children. Mary Ann owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over fifteen years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2007, Mary Ann joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Mary Ann is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be her sixth from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en: Rosemarie L., 29 years old, is a married woman who supports her family by fish vending. She lives in Sto. Catinggib, Barangay Suay, Himamaylan City, Negros Occidental, with her husband and their three children who are between 5 and 10 years old and still studying. Rosemarie has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2000 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her fish-vending business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 18,000. Rosemarie is now borrowing Php 12,000 so that she is able to expand her fish-vending business. This will be her 15th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of Php 10,000 was paid off within its term and was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Rosemarie aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the “Dungganon” way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital for her business

loans.name: Maria Analiza

texts.en: Maria Analiza is a 42-year-old married woman who lives in Bakyas, Barangay Cabanbanan, Himamaylan City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by selling jewelry. Maria Analiza’s 42 year old husband, John, has his own job in order to support his family. They have one child who is currently going to school and who also helps out in the business as part of the daily chores. Maria Analiza joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2001 with the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in jewelry retailing. Now she earns an average monthly income of Php 5,000. Maria Analiza is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of Php 18,000 was used to fund operations of her jewelry business and had a positive impact on both the business and on the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing Php 18,000 for her 11th loan which she intends to use for her jewelry business. Maria Analiza is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which are to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital for her business

loans.name: Vanna

texts.en:
Mrs. Vanna M., age 37, and her husband, Mr. Khoeun Khiev, 39, (pictured together) were married in 1993 and have three children: one son and two daughters. The family lives along the Tonle Basac River, a tributary of the nearby Mekong River, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.
	
Vanna is a farmer and grows jasmine flowers on her farmland. Besides farming, she also sells jasmine flowers at the market in Phnom Penh. Some she buys from farmers in the village for resale, some are from her own farm. Her husband has been a construction worker for eighteen years, working in the village.

Vanna is requesting her first loan in the amount of US$1,100 to purchase jasmine flowers from farmers on contract. She needs to pay money to the farmers first before the harvest season.

loans.use: To purchase jasmine flowers from farmers under contract

loans.name: Valiente's Group

texts.en: Valiente A. is from the village of Turod. He is 30 years old and is the group leader of a ten-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Valiente is married and has two school-aged children. He owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. He has been engaged in his business for over four years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Valiente joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be his first from ASKI. Valiente plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Nida

texts.en: Nida L. is a married woman who supports her family by fish vending. She lives in Sto. Catinggib, Barangay Suay, Himamaylan City, Negros Occidental, with her husband and their three children who are between the ages of 16 and 19 years. All three children are attending school. Nida has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2005 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her fish-vending business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 12,000. Nida is now borrowing Php 10,000 so that she can expand her fish-vending business. This will be her 11th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of Php 13,000, which she paid off within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Nida aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the “Dungganon” way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital for her business

loans.name: Tomasa's Group

texts.en: Tomasa B. is from the village of Calamagui, San Pablo, Isabela. She is 46 years old and is the group leader of a twelve-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Tomasa is married and has six school-aged children. She owns and operates a business raising and fattening pigs for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over twenty years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. Tomasa joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. Tomasa is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her second from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Toyin

texts.en:
Toyin sells cement blocks to earn a living. She loves this business because it is highly profitable. She is requesting the loan amount of NGN 150,000 to purchase more bags of cement and sand to mold more blocks to sell. She hires laborers to mold the blocks for her to sell. Her customers are usually home-owners and building contractors. She hopes to be a major cement block distributor in the future.

Toyin is 40 years old and married to Mr. O. who is an accountant. They have four children. Toyin says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of cement and sand to mold more blocks to sell

loans.name: Sokhorn

texts.en:
Mr. Sokhorn S., 59, and his wife, Mrs. Oeun Ben (pictured together), 54, have been married since 1980 and have two sons and four daughters. One of them is married and lives outside the family home. Three children have full-time employment, and the other three children attend school. The family is living in a small village along National Road Number Two, about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Sokhorn has been driving a motor remorque taxi (motorbike with trailer attached at the back) since 1994. He carries people and goods from his area to Phnom Penh and back. His wife stays at home to take care of their children. Sokhorn asked for a loan to purchase a motorbike for his son to drive to work. And his son used the motorbike to go to work every day.

Sokhorn now is asking for another loan in the amount of $500 to purchase another motorbike for his children who are attending school to drive to school.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle for his children to drive to school

loans.name: Deborah

texts.en:
Deborah has a shop where she sells drinks and juice. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. Deborah is requesting the loan amount of NGN 100,000 to purchase more juice and drinks to sell. She hopes to own a world class juice and wine shop in the future.

Deborah is married to a clergyman and they have a child. She hopes to give quality education to her child. She says thank you and promises to repay her loan promptly.

loans.use: To purchase more juice and drinks to sell

loans.name: Arlene's Group

texts.en:
Arlene H. is from the village of Little Tadian, Alfonsolista, Ifugao. She is 25 years old. Arlene is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Arlene is married and has one infant. To make a living, Arlene owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector, running a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Arlene has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Arlene joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Arlene is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Arlene from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: An

texts.en:
Mrs. An H. (pictured here), age 62, is a widow with three sons and two daughters who weave silk at home. One of them is married and lives in a separate home; one is a construction worker, and another one attends school. They are living on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Mrs. An H. has been a silk weaver since she was young. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village who then brings them to sell in Phnom Penh market. She is requesting a loan in the amount of $700 to purchase silk material for her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.name: Kalbubu's Group

texts.en:
Some years ago, Kalbubu U. did not think that life would be difficult or that she would have to fight for a place in the sun. However, after both her and her husband were fired from their highly paid jobs, they both faced many difficulties. They had to do something to survive and move on. Understanding their troubles, Kalbubu's parents gave them a cow. This was the first step in making their life better. Ten years ago, after receiving that great “gift”, they started a business milking the cow and selling the milk. Day by day, the family's budget increased. Now, after coming up the hard way, they have daily bread.
Kalbubu is now 42 and a brilliant mother of two children. The eldest is 20 and, in order not to be a burden to his parents, works for a company that produces national soft drinks as kymyz, ayran and shoro (cultured Kyrgyz milk drinks). The younger child is 14 and goes to the local school – he is a smart and hardworking boy who helps his parents with the chores. Together, the family raise cattle and Kalbubu's husband does a portage. Their profit in total is 11,500 KGS. At the moment, they are planning to renovate their house. Kalbubu is requesting a loan to buy a bull-calf for fattening and selling later.
Indira K. is 35, married, and the marvelous mother of three children. Her husband works on the railways. Her elder son is 16 and studies at college, her daughter attends the local school, and she also has a cute little son, who is 4. Indira fattens horses and sells them on. She started this business 16 years ago when her parents gave a foal to her first son as a birthday gift. Over time, she has increased her number of horses and has bought a car. She earns 7,000 KGS per month and is requesting a loan to buy calves for fattening and selling on.
Jibek M. is 37, widowed, and has three children. Her eldest son is 18 and has already graduated from a specialized school, her daughter is 16 and attends college, and her youngest son is 11 and goes to school. Her revenue from selling provisions is 7,000 KGS per month. However, she did not think that from selling a cow last year for 15,000 KGS, she would start a really good business. She is planning to help her children find jobs and save up some money for their marriages. She is requesting a loan to buy goods to increase turnover and the variety of goods she offers.
Oksana K. is 32 and married to a man who works in distillery as a mason. She has two daughters; the elder is 11 and the younger is 7. They both go to school. Oksana has an animal breeding business, fattening both sheep and bull-calves and then selling them. With a loan and initial capital of 100,000 KGS about 8 years ago, her revenue is now 9,500 KGS. She has bought a car and is planning to replace it in the future, and also wants to build a new house. She is requesting another loan to buy bull-calves for fattening and selling.


Where did this loan come from?
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further), and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team – Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy a bull-calf for fattening and selling

loans.name: Bosede

texts.en: Bosede  is married to a land surveyor and they have four children. She has a shop where she sells drinks to make a living. She loves her business because of the one-to-one interaction that she has with her customers. Bosede is requesting a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more drinks to sell. In the future, she hopes to own a world-class drinks shop and be able to give her children a good quality education. She says thank you and promises to repay her Kiva loan promptly.

loans.use: To purchase drinks to sell

loans.name: Chantha

texts.en:
Mr. Chantha M., aged 40, and his wife, Mrs. Thouk Chorn, aged 38, live in a small village along National Road Number Three, about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 1988 and have four children. Their two sons repair motorcycles while their two daughters work in a garment factory. Chantha was not available for the photo, so his wife is pictured instead.
Chantha has been selling cows and oxen since he married. He buys them from other districts for resale to a middleman who comes to buy from him at his house. Mrs. Thouk Chorn stays at home and does housework.
Chantha wants to expand his business in order to generate income to support his family as his business is the main source of family income. Therefore, he is applying for his first loan of $1,000 USD in order to buy additional cows and oxen for resale.

loans.use: To buy additional cows and oxen for resale

loans.name: Kemi

texts.en:
Kemi is 34 years old and married with four children. Her husband is a welder and he also supports the home. Kemi is a client of Kiva partner, Lift Above Poverty Organiation (LAPO), and she sells frozen foods, such as turkey, beef and fish. She has been in this business for a long time. She is requesting a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more frozen foods to sell. Kemi says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

About LAPO
Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.

loans.use: To purchase more frozen foods to sell

loans.name: Bolotova Rayma's Group

texts.ru:
Болотова Райма, является лидером данной группы.Ей 53 года, но все еще она активная бизнесвумен. Райма замужем, воспитывает единственную дочь. Ее дочери 20 лет, она студентка 3 курса строительного университета. Учится в столице Кыргызстана, в Бишкеке. Супруг пенсионер, и все свое время ухаживает за животными. Семья клиента занимается животноводством,  у них свое хозяйство состоящее из 5 КРС и 10 МРС. Кредит будет использован для закупа 1 коровы для откорма и последующей реализации. Как и большинство людей, она очень усердно работает, чтобы улучшить уровень жизни ее семьи. 

Омурбеку 45 лет. Он женат, имеет трех дочерей. Все дочери учаться в школе. Супруга домохозяйка. Сам Омурбек также занимается животноводством на протяжении последних 16 лет. Кредит будет использован для закупа 1 теленка. Стоит отметить, что до этого он никогда не работал с заемными средствами. Средняя прибыль в месяц равна 75 долларам.
 
Акин 55 лет, она замужем. У нее 1 сын. Супруг пенсионер, активно участвует в семейном бизнесе (животноводство), а также вместе с сыном дома изготавливают деревянные окна, столы, стулья и прочие. Она является казначеем группы и ответственна за собирание ежемесячной выплаты и погашения ее в Мол Булак Финанс. Кредит будет использован для закупа 2 голов КРС. 

Нурзат 30 лет, она замужем. У нее дочь и сын, оба детей дошкольного возраста. Супруг работает таксистом. Нурзат имеет свой собственный магазин по продаже продуктов питания. В этом бизнесе она три года. Кредит будет использован для увеличения товарооборота в магазине.

Гулбаре  55 лет. Она вдова. У нее семеро детей, самому старшему уже 37 лет, а младшему 13.  Старшие две дети на заработках в России. У нее есть собственное хозяйство, где она выращивает МРС и КРС, а также на земельном наделе выращивает картошку. Кредит будет использован для весенних полевых работ.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
Rayma B. is the leader of this group. She is 53 years old, but still an active businesswoman. Rayma is married and is raising her only daughter. Her daughter is 20 years old. She is a 3rd year student at a construction university. She is studying in Bishkek, the capital of Kyrgyzstan. Rayma’s husband is retired and spends all of his time taking care of animals. The client’s family is involved in animal husbandry and has a household consisting of 5 cattle and 10 small livestock. The loan will be used for the purchase of 1 cow for raising and subsequent sale. Just like many people, Rayma works diligently in order to improve her family’s quality of life. Omurbek is 45 years old. He is married and has three daughters. All of the daughters are in school. His wife is a homemaker. Omurbek has also been involved in animal husbandry for the last 16 years. He will use this loan to purchase one calf. It is relevant to note that he never worked with borrowed funds. His average monthly profit equals 75 dollars. Akin is 55 years old. She is married and has 1 son. Her husband is retired and actively involved in the family business (animal husbandry). He and his son also make wood window frames, tables, chairs and the like at home. Akin is the treasurer of the group and is responsible for collecting monthly payments and repaying loans with Mol Bulak Finance. The loan will be used for the purchase of two cows. Nurzat is 30 years old. She is married and has a daughter and a son, both of whom are of pre-school age. Her husband works as a taxi driver. Nurzat owns a food products store. She has been in this business for three years. The loan will be used for increasing product turnover in the store. Gulbara is 55 years old. She is a widow and has seven children. The oldest is already 37 years old, and the youngest is 13. Two of her oldest children are working in Russia. Gulbara has her own household, where she raises small livestock and cattle. She also has a plot of land, where she grows potatoes. The loan will be used for the spring field work.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of a cow

loans.name: Julieta's Group

texts.en:
Julieta V. is from the village of Mocag, Baggao, Cagayan. She is 48 years old and the leader of a 13-member group loan offered by Kiva partner, ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.
Julieta is married and has four adult-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Julieta has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from these activities.
In 2009, Julieta joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. Julieta is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be her second from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family.

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Sokleang

texts.en:
Mr. Sokleang S. (pictured here), 47, and his wife, Mrs. Saing Korn, 40, have been married since 1991 and have five children: three sons and two daughters. One of their children is a garment factory worker and three are in school. The family lives in a small village located 17 kilometers south of Phnom Penh City.
Sokleang has been driving a motor remoque (a motorcycle with a trailer attached at the back) for more than two years. His wife has been a garment factory worker for more than five years. When she has free time, she grows vegetable as well. Sokleang assists his wife in farming. He is asking for a loan of $1,000 USD to make the roof of his house and dig a well for his family to use.

loans.use: To make the roof of his house and dig a well for his family

loans.name: Adebisi

texts.en: Adebisi is 37 years old, married, and has three children, the eldest of whom is 14 years old. Her children are excelling in school and this gives her joy and peace. Her husband is a mechanic and he also supports the home. Adebisi is a hardworking woman and is determined to excel. She sells hair extensions and cream at retail prices to her customers. She loves her business because it is highly competitive. Adebisi is requesting a loan of 80,000 NGN to purchase more hair extensions and cream to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders and promises to repay her loan promptly.

loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions and cream to sell
